editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Trick to catch the Old-one. As it hath beene lately Acted, by the Children of Paules.
AT LONDON Printed by George Eld, and are to be ſold at his houſe in Fleete-lane at the ſigne of the Printers-Preſſe. 1608.

div.head: A Trick to catch the old one.

sp.speaker: Witt-good.
sp.p: ALL's gone! ſtill thou'rt a Gentleman, that's all; but a poore one, that's nothing: What Milke brings thy Meadowes forth now? where are thy goodly Vp-lands and thy Downe-lands, all ſunck into that little pitte Lecherie? why ſhould a Gallant pay but two ſhillings for his Ordnary that nouriſhes him, and twenty times two for his Brothell that conſumes him? but where's Long-acre? in my Vncles conſcience, which is 3. yeares voyage about; he that ſetts out vpon his conſcience, nere finds the way home againe, he is either ſwallowed in the quick-ſands of Law-quillits, or ſplits vpō the Piles of a Praemunire; yet theſe old Foxe-braind—and oxe-browde Vncles, haue ſtill defences for their Auarice, and Apologies for their practiſes, and will thus greete our follyes.

lg.l: Hee that doth his youth expoſe,
Let him that is his neereſt Kinne,

sp.p: And that's his Vncle, 'tis a principle in Vſury; I dare not viſit the Cittie, there I ſhould bee too ſoone viſited, by that horrible plague my Debts, and by that meanes I looſe a Virgins loue, her portion and her Vertues, well, how ſhould a man liue now, that ha's no liuing; hum? why are there not a million of men in the world, that onely ſoiourne vpon their braine, and make their wittes their Mercers; and am I but one amongſt that Million and cannot thriue vpon't; any Trick out of the compaſſe of Lawe now, would come happily to me.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: My loue.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: My lothing; haſt thou beene the ſecret conſumption of my purſe? and now comſt to vndo my laſt meanes, my wits? wilt leaue no vertue in me and yet thou nere the better? hence Curtizan, round webd Tarantula.
That dryeſt the Roſes in the cheekes of youth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I haue beene true vnto your pleaſure, and all your lands thrice rackt, was neuer worth the Iewell which I prodigally gaue you, my virginity;
Lands morgag'd may returne and more eſteemde,
But honeſty once pawnd, is nere redeemd.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: For giue I do thee wrong,
To make thee ſinne, and then to chid thee fort.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I know I am your loathing now, farewell.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Stay beſt inuention,—ſtay.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I that haue beene the ſecret conſumption of your purſe ſhall I ſtay now to vndo your laſt meanes, your witts? hence Currizan away.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I prethee, make me not mad at my owne weapon, ſtay, (a thing few women can do I know that, and therefore they had need weare ſtayes;) be not contrary, doſt loue me?
Fate has ſo caſt it that all my meanes I muſt deriue from thee.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: From me! be happy then,
What lies within the power of my performance,
Shall be commanded of thee.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Spoke like an honeſt drab ifaith, it may proue ſom-thing what Trick is not an Embrion at firſt, vntil a perfect ſhape come ouer it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Come I muſt helpe you where abouts left you,
Ile proceed.
Tho you beget, tis I muſt helpe to breed,
Speake what iſt, Ide faine conceaue it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo, thou ſhall preſently take the name and forme vpon thee of a rich country widdow foure hundred a yeare valiant, in Woods, in Bullocks, in Barnes and in Rye-ſtacks, weele to London▪ and to my couetous Vncle.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I begin to applaud thee, our States beeing both deſperate, they' are ſoone reſolute, but how for horſes?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Maſſe that's true, the Ieſt will bee of ſome continuance, let mee ſee, Horſes now, a bottes on em; Stay, I haue acquaintance with a madde Hoſte, neuer yet Bawde to thee, I haue rinzde the whoreſons gums in Mull-ſack many a time and often, put but a good Tale into his eare now, ſo it come off cleanely, and there's Horſe and man for vs I dare warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Arme your wittes then ſpeedily, there ſhall want nothing in mee, eyther in behauiour, diſcourſe or faſhion, that ſhall diſcredit your entended purpoſe.
I will ſo art-fully diſguiſe my wants,
And ſet ſo good a courage on my ſtate,
That I will be beleeued.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why then all's furniſht; I ſhall goe nigh to catch that olde Foxe mine Vncle, tho hee make but ſome amends for my vndooing, yet there's ſome comfort in't — hee cannot otherwiſe chooſe (tho it bee but in hope to coozen mee agen) but ſupply any haſtie want that I bring to towne with mee, the Deuice well and cunningly carryed, the name of a riche Widdow, and foure hundred a yeare in good earth, will ſo coniure vp a kinde of Vſurers loue in him to mee, that hee will not onely deſire my preſence, which at firſt ſhall ſcarce bee granted him, Ile keepe off a purpoſe, but I ſhall finde him ſo officious to deſerue, ſo ready to ſupply, I know the ſtate of an old mans affection ſo well, if his Nephew bee poore indeed, why hee letts God alone with him, but if hee be once rich, then heele bee the firſt man that helpes him.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Tis right the world, for in theſe dayes an olde mans loue to his kindred, is like his kindneſſe to his wife, 'tis alwayes done before hee comes at it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
I owe thee for that Ieſt, bee gone, here's all my wealth; prepare thy ſelfe, away? Ile to mine Hoſte withall poſſible haſt, and with the beſt Art, & moſt profitable forme, powre the ſweet
circumſtance into his eare, which ſhall haue the gift to turne all the waxe to hunny; how no; oh the right worſhipful Seniors of our Country —
Whoſe that;
Oh the common Rioter, take no note of him.

sp.speaker: Witg.
sp.p: You will not ſee me now, the comfort is ere it be long you will ſcarce ſee your ſelues.
I wonder how hee breathes, ha's conſum'd all vpon that Curtizan?
We haue heard ſo much.

sp.l: You have heard all truth, his Vncle and my Brother, haue beene theſe three yeares mortall Aduerſaries. Two old tough ſpirits, they ſeldome meete but fight, or quarrell when tis calmeſt;
I thinke their anger bee the very fire
That keepes their age aliue:

sp.p: What was the quarrell ſir?

Faith about a purchaſe, fetching ouer a yong heire; Maiſter Hoord my brother hauing waſted much time in beating the bargayne, what did me old Lucre▪ but as his conſcience mou'd him, knowing the poore Gentleman▪ ſtept in betweene e'm and couzned him himſelfe.
And was this all ſir:

This was e'en it ſir, yet for all this I know no reaſon but the match might go forward betwixt his wiues Sonne and my Neece, what tho there bee a diſſention betweene the two olde men, I ſee no reaſon it ſhould put a difference betweene the two yonger, tis as naturall for old folkes to fall out, as for yong to fall in? A ſcholler comes a wooing to my Neece, well, hee's wiſe, but he's poore, her Sonne comes a wooing to my Neece, well, hees a foole, but hees rich —
I marry ſir?
Pray now is not a rich foole better then a poore Philoſopher.
One would think ſo yfaith?

She now remaines at London with my brother her ſecond
Vncle, to learne faſhions, practiſe Muſicke, the voyce betweene her lips, and the violl betweene her legges, ſhee'le bee fitt for a conſort very ſpeedily, a thouſand good pound is her portion, if ſhe marry, weele ride vp and be merry,—
A match, if it be a match?

div.stage: Enter at one doore, Witt-good, at the other Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Young maiſter Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit,
sp.p: I haue beene laying all the Towne for thee.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why what's the newes Bully-Hadland?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What Geldings are in the houſe of thine owne? anſwer me to that firſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why man, why?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Marke mee what I ſay, Ile tell thee ſuch a tale in thine eare, that thou ſhalt truſt mee ſpite of thy teeth, furniſh me with ſome money, wille, nille, and ride vp with mee thy ſelfe Contra voluntatem et profeſſion em.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: How: let me ſee this trick, and Ile ſay thou haſt more
Arte then a Coniurer.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Dooſt thou ioy in my aduancement?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Do I loue Sack and Ginger?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Comes my proſperitie deſiredly to thee?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Come forfeitures to a Vſurer, fees to an officer, punkes to an Hoſte, and Pigs to a Parſon deſiredly? why then la.

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: Will the report of a Widdow of foure hundred a yeare boye, make thee leape, and ſing, and dance, and come to thy place agen.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Wilt thou command me now? I am thy ſpirit, coniure me into any ſhape.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
I ha brought her from her friends, turnde backe the Horſes by a ſlight, not ſo much as one amongſt her ſixe men, goodly large Yeomanly fellowes, will ſhee truſt with this her purpoſe: by this light all vnmand; regardleſſe of her ſtate, neglectfull of vaine-glorious ceremonie, all for my loue; oh 'tis a
fine little voluble toung mine Hoſte, that wins a widdow.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: No 'tis a toung with a great T my boye that winnes a widdow.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Now ſir, the caſe ſtands thus, good mine Hoſt, if thou lou'ſt my happineſſe aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Command all my beaſts ith houſe.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Nay thats not all neither, prethee take truce with thy ioy, and liſten to mee, thou know'ſt I haue a wealthy Vncle i'th Citty, ſome-what the wealthier by my follyes; the report of this fortune well and cunningly carried, might be a meanes to drawe ſome goodneſſe from the Vſuring Raſcall, for I haue put her in hope already of ſome eſtate that I haue eyther in land or money: now if I be found true in neither, what may I expect but a ſuddaine breach of our loue, vtter diſſolution of the match, and confuſion of my fortunes for euer.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Wilt thou but truſt the managing of thy buſineſſe with me?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: With thee? why will I deſire to thriue in my purpoſe? will I hugge foure hundred a yeare? I that know the miſery of nothing? will that man wiſh a riche widdow, that has nere a hole to put his head in? with thee mine Hoſte, why beleeue it, ſooner with thee then with a Couy of Counſellors?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Thanke you for your good report yfaith ſir, and if I ſtand you not inſteed, why then let an Hoſte come off Hic & haec hoſtis, a deadly enemie to Dice, Drinke, and Venery; come where's this widdow?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Hard at Parke-end.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Ile be her Seruing-man for once.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why there wee let off together, keepe full time, my thoughts were ſtriking then iuſt the ſame number.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I knew't, ſhall we then ſee our merry dayes agen?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Our merry nights—which nere ſhall bee more ſeene.

div.stage: Enter at ſeuerall doores, old Lucre, and old Hoord, Gentlemen comming betweene them, to pacifie 'em.

sp.speaker: Lampr.
sp.p: Nay good Maiſter Lucre, and you Maiſter Hoord▪ anger is the winde which you▪re both too much troubled with all.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Shall my aduerſary thus dayly afront mee, ripping vp the old wound of our malice, which three Summers could not cloſe vp, into which wound the very ſight of him, drops ſcalding Lead inſteed of Balſamum.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord; may I not paſſe in the ſtate of quietneſſe to mine owne houſe, anſwer mee to that▪ before witneſſe, and why? Ile referre the cauſe to honeſt euen-minded Gentlemen, or require the meere indifferences of the Lawe, to decide this matter, I got the purchaſe, true; was't not any mans caſe? yes, will a wiſe-man ſtand as a Bawd, whilſt another wipes his noſe of the bargaine, no, I anſwer no in that caſe.

sp.speaker: Lampr.
sp.p: Nay ſweet Maiſter Lucre.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Was it the part of a friend: no, rather of a Iew, marke what I ſay, when I had beaten the buſh to the laſt bird, or as I may terme it, the price to a pound, then like a cunning Vſurer to come in the euening of the bargaine, and gleane all my hopes in a minute, to enter as it were at the back-doore of the purchaſe, for thou nere camſt the right way by it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Haſt thou the conſcience to tell mee ſo, without any impeachment to thy ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Thou that canſt defeate thy owne Nephew, Lucre, lap his lands into bonds, and take the extremity of thy kindreds forfeitures becauſe hee's a rioter, a waſt-thrift, a brothell-maiſter, and ſo forth— what may a Stranger expect from thee, but Ʋulnera delacerata, as the Poet ſayes, delacerate dealing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Vpbraidſt thou me with Nephew? is all imputation laid vpon me? what acquaintance haue I with his follyes, if hee riott, 'tis hee muſt want it, if hee ſurfet, 'tis hee muſt feele it:
if he Drab it, 'tis he muſt lye by't, what's this to me?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: What's all to thee? nothing, nothing; ſuch is the gulfe of thy deſire, and the Wolfe of thy conſcience, but be aſſured old pecunious lucre, if euer fortune ſo bleſſe me, that I may be at leiſure to vexe thee, or any meanes ſo fauour me, that I may haue oportunitie to mad thee, I will purſue it with that flame of hate, that ſpirit of malice, vnrepreſſed wrath, that I will blaſt thy comforts.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay maiſter Hoord you▪re a wiſe Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: I will ſo croſſe thee,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And I thee.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: So without mercy fret thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So monſtrouſly oppoſe thee?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Dooſt ſcoffe at my iuſt anger? oh that I had as much power as vſury ha's ouer thee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then thou wouldſt haue as much power as the deuill ha's ouer thee.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Toade!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Aſpick.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Serpent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Viper.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, then we muſt diuide you perforce.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: When the fire growes too vnreaſonable hotte, ther's no better way then to take of the wood.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A word good Signior.

sp.speaker: Mony.
sp.p: How now, what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: 'Tis giuen mee to vnderſtand, that you are a riuall of mine in the loue of Miſtreſſe Ioyce, maiſter Hoords Neece: ſay mee I, ſay me no.

sp.speaker: Mony.
sp.p: Yes, tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Then looke to your ſelfe, you cannot liue long, Ime practizing euery morning, a moneth hence Ile challenge you.

sp.speaker: Monyt.
sp.p: Giue mee your hand vpon't ther's my pledge Ile meete you?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh, oh—what reaſon had you for that ſir to ſtrike before the mouth, you knew I was not ready for you, and that made you ſo cranck, I am not ſuch a coward to ſtrike agen I warrant you, my eare has the lawe of her ſide for it burnes horribly, I will teach him to ſtrike a naked face, the longeſt day of his life, ſlid it ſhall coſt me ſome money, but Ile bring this boxe into the Chancery.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Feare you nothing ſir, I haue lodgd her in a houſe of credit I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Haſt thou the writings?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Firme ſir

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Prethee ſtay, and behold two the moſt prodigious raſcals that euer ſlipt into the ſhape of men, Dampit ſirrah, and young Gulfe, his fellow Cater-piller.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Dampit? ſure I haue heard of that Dampit.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Heard of him? why man he that ha's loſt both his eares, may heare of him, a famous infamous Trampler of time; his owne phraze: note him well, that Dampit ſirrah, hee in the vneuen Beard, and the Serge cloake, is the moſt notorious, vſuring, blaſphemous, Atheiſticall, Brothell, vomiting raſcall, that wee haue in theſe latter times now extant, whoſe firſt beginning was the ſtealing of a maſtie Dogge from a Farmers houſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Hee lookt as if hee would obay the commandement well, when he began firſt with ſtealing.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: True, the next Towne he came at, hee ſet the Dogs together by'th eares.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A ſigne he ſhould follow the law by my faith.

sp.speaker: Ʋ Ʋitt.
sp.p:
So it followed indeed, and beeing deſtitute of all fortunes, ſtakte his Maſtie againſt a Noble, and by great fortune his Dogge had the day, how hee made it vp ten ſhillings I know not, but his owne boaſt is, that hee came to towne but
with ten ſhillings in his purſe, and now is credibly worth tenne thouſand pound?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: How the deuill came he by it?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How the deuill came he not by it, if you put in the deuill once riches come with a vengeance, has beene a Trampler of the Law ſir, and the deuill has a care of his footemen, the Roague has ſpied me now, hee nibled me finely once too; a poxe ſearch you, oh maiſter Dampit, the very Loynes of thee; crie you mercie maiſter Gulfe, you walke ſo lowe I promiſe you I ſawe you not ſir?

sp.speaker: Gulf.
sp.p: Hee that walkes lowe walkes ſafe, the Poets tell vs.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And nyer hell by a foote and a halfe then the reſt of his fellowes, but my old Harry.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: My ſweete Theodorus?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Twas a merry world when thou cam'ſt to towne with ten ſhillings in thy purſe.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: And now worth ten thouſand pound my Boye, report it, Harry Dampit, a trampler of time, ſay, hee would bee vp in a morning, and be here with his Serge Gowne, daſht vp to the hams in a cauſe, haue his feete ſtincke about VVeſtminſter hall and come home agen, ſee the Galleouns, the Galleaſſes the great Armadoes of the Lawe, then there bee Hoyes and pettie veſſells, Owers and Scullers of the time, there bee picklocks of the Time too, then would I bee here, I would trample vp and downe like a Mule; now to the Iudges, may it pleaſe your reuerend—honorable father-hoods: then to my Counſellor, may it pleaſe your worſhipfull patience, then to the examiners Office, may it pleaſe your Maiſterſhippes Gentleneſſe, then to one of the Clarkes, may it pleaſe your worſhipfull Lowzineſſe, for I finde him ſcrubbing in his codpeice, then to the hall agen, then to the Chamber agen;

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And when to the ſellar agen?

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p:
E'en when thou wilt agen; Tramplers of time, Motions of Fleete-ſtreete, and Viſions of Holborne, here I haue
fees of one, there I haue fees of another, my clients come about me, the Fooli-aminy and Cockſ-combri of the Country, I ſtil traſht and trotted for other mens cauſes, thus was poore Harry Dampit made rich by others lazineſſe, who, tho they would not follow their owne Suites, I made e'm follow mee with their purſes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Did'ſt thou ſo old Harry?

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: I, and I ſouc'ſt e'm with bills of Charges ifayth, twentie pound a yeare haue I brought in for boate-hire, and I nere ſtept into boate in my life.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Tramplers of time.

sp.speaker: Dampit.
sp.p: I, Tramplers of time, Raſkalls of time, Bulbeggars:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ah thou'rt a mad old Harrie? kinde Maiſter Gulfe, I am bould to renew my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Gulf.
sp.p: I embrace it ſir.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: My Aduerſary euermore twittes mee with my Nephew, forſooth my Nephew: why may not a vertuous vncle haue a diſſolute Nephewe? what tho hee bee a Brotheller, a waſt-thrift, a common Surfetter, and to conclude a beggar, muſt ſinne in him, call vp ſhame in mee: ſince wee haue no part in their follies, why ſhould wee haue part in their infamies? for my ſtrickt hand toward his morgage that I denie not, I confeſſe I had an Vncles penworth: let me ſee, halfe in halfe, true, I ſawe neyther hope of his reclayming, nor comfort in his beeing, and was it not then better beſtow'd vpon his Vncle, then vpon one of his Aunts, I neede not ſay bawde, for euery owne knowes what Aunt ſtands for in the laſt Tranſlation now ſir.

sp.speaker: Ser. 2.
sp.p: Ther's a Country Seruing-man ſir, attends to ſpeake with your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ime at beſt leiſure now, ſend him in to me;

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Bleſſe your venerable worſhip.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Welcome good fellow.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Hee calles me theefe at firſt ſight, yet he little thinkes I am an Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's thy buſines with me?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Faith ſir, I am ſent from my Miſtriſſe to any ſufficient Gentleman indeed, to aske aduiſe vpon a doubtfull point, 'tis indifferent ſir, to whome I come, for I know none, nor did my Miſtres direct mee to any perticuler man, for ſhee's as meere a ſtranger here as my ſelfe, onely I found your worſhip within, and tis a thing I euer lou'd ſir to be diſpacht as ſoone as I can:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: A good blunt honeſty, I like him wel what is thy Miſtres?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Fayth a Cuntry Gentlewoman and a widdow ſir, yeſterday was the firſt flight of vs, but now ſhee entends to ſtay till a little Tearme buſineſſe be ended.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Her name I prethee?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: It runnes there in the writings ſir, among her Lands, widdow Medler?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Meddler? maſſe haue I neere heard of that widdow?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Yes, I wa •• nt you, haue you ſir, not the rich widdowe in Staffordſheere:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Cuds me, there tis indeede, thou haſt put me into memorie, there's a widdow indeed, ah that I were a batchiler agen.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: No doubt your worſhip might do much then, but ſhe's fayrely promiſt to a bachiler already.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ah what is he I prethee?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: A Country Gentleman too, one whome your worſhip knowes not Ime ſure: has ſpent ſome fewe follies in his youth, but marriage by my fayth begins to call him home, my Miſtris loues him ſir, and loue couers faults you know, one maiſter VVit-good if euer you haue heard of the Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha? Wit-good ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Thats his name indeede ſir; my Miſtris is like to bring him to a goodly ſeate yonder, foure hundred a yeare by my faith,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But I pray take me with you.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I ſir▪

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What Countryman might this yong Wit-good be?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: A Leſterſhire gentleman ſir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My Nephew, by th▪ maſſe my Nephew, Ile fetch out more of this yfaith, a ſimple Country fellow, Ile workte out of him, and is that Gentleman ſayſt thou preſently to marrie her?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Fayth he brought her vp to towne ſir, has the beſt card in all the bunch fort, her heart: and I know my Miſtris will bee married, ere ſhe goe downe, nay Ile ſweare that, for ſhe's none of thoſe widdowes that will goe downe firſt, and bee married after, ſhe hates that I can tell you ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: By my faith ſir, ſhee is like to haue a proper Gentleman and a comelie, Ile giue her that gift?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why do's your worſhip know him ſir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know him! dos not all the world knowe him, can a man of ſuch exquiſite qualities be hid vnder a buſhell?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Then your worſhippe may ſaue mee a labour, for I had charge giuen me to enquire after him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Enquire of him? if I might counſell thee, thou ſhouldſt nere trouble thy ſelfe furder, enquire of him of no more but of mee, Ile fit thee? I grant he has beene youthfull, but is he not now reclaimde; marke you that ſir, has not your Miſtris thinke you beene wanton in her youth? if men bee wagges, are there not women wagtayles?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: No doubt ſir:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Do's not he returne wiſeſt, that comes home whipt with his owne follies.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Why very true ſir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: The worſt report you can heare of him I can tell you is that hee has beene a kinde Gentleman, a liberall and a worthie, who but luſtie Wit-good, thrice Noble Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p:
Since your worſhippe has ſo much knowledge in him,
can you reſolue me Sir what his liuing might bee, my duty bindes me ſir to haue a care of my miſtris eſtate, ſhe has beene euer a good miſtris to me though I ſay it, many welthy Suiters has ſhee Nonſuted for his ſake, yet tho her Loue bee ſo fixt, a man cannot tell whether his Non-performance may helpe to remoue it ſir; hee makes vs beleeue hee has lands and liuing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who young maiſter Wit-good! why beleeue it he has as goodly a fine liuing out yonder, what do you call the place?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Nay I know not ifaith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hum, ſee like a Beaſt if I haue not forgot the name, puh, and out yonder agen, goodly growen woods and faire meado ves, pax ont, I can nere hit of that place neither, hee; why hes Wit-good of Wit-good-Hall, hee, an vnknowe thing.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Is he ſo ſir, to ſee how rumor will alter, truſt me ſir we heard once he had no lands, but all lay morgagde to an Vncle he has in towne here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Puſh, tis a tale, tis a tale.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I can aſſure you ſir twas credibly reported to my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why doe you thinke ifaith hee was euer ſo ſimple to morgage his lands to his Vncle? or his vncle ſo vnnaturall to take the extremity of ſuch a morgage.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: That was my ſaying ſtill ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Puh, nere thinke it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yet that report goes currant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay then you vrge me,
Cannot I tell that beſt that am his Vncle,

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: How ſir! what haue I donne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why how now in a Sowne, man▪

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Is your worſhip his Vncle ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Can that be any harme to you ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p:
I do beſeech your ſir do me the fauour to conceale it, what a Beaſt was I to vtter ſo much: pray ſir doe mee the kindneſſe to keepe it in, I ſhall haue my coate pull'd ore my
eares, ant ſhould bee knowne, for the truth is an't pleaſe your worſhippe, to preuent much rumour and many ſuiters, they entend to bee married verie ſuddenly and priuately.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: And do'ſt thou thinke it ſtands with my Iudgement to doe them iniury, muſt I needes ſay the knowledge of this marriage comes from thee? am I a foole at fifty foure? doe I lacke ſubteltie now that haue got all my wealth by it? there's a leaſh of Angells for thee, come let mee wo thee, ſpeake where lie they?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: So I might haue no anger ſir—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Paſſion of me not a iot, prethe come.

sp.speaker: Hoſtis.
sp.p: I would not haue it knowne it came by my meanes,—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why am I a man of wiſdome?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I dare truſt your worſhip ſir, but I'me a ſtranger to your houſe, and to auoyde al Intelligencers I deſire your worſhippes eare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This fellowe's worth a matter of truſt—come ſir, why now thou'rt an honeſt lad: ah ſirrah Nephew?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Pleaſe you ſir now I haue begunne with your worſhip when ſhall I attend, for your aduice vpon that doubtfull poynt, I muſt come warily now.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Tut, feare thou nothing, to morrowes euening ſhall reſolue the doubt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: The time ſhall cauſe my attendance.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Fare thee well: there's more true honeſty in ſuch a Cuntrie Seruingman, then in a hundred of our cloake companions, I may well call e'm companions, for ſince blew coates haue beene turn'd into cloakes, wee can ſcarce knowe the man from the Maiſter—George—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Anon ſir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Liſt hether,—keepe the place ſecret, commend mee to my Nephewe, I knowe no cauſe tell him but hee might ſee his Vncle?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And doe you heare ſir, take heede you vſe him with reſpect and duty.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Here's a ſtrange alteration, one day he muſt be turnd out like a Beggar, and now he muſt be cald in like a Knight!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah Sirrah, that rich widdow, 400. a yeare, beſide I here ſhe layes Clayme to a title of a hundred more, this falls vnhappily that he ſhould beare a Grudge to me now being likely to proue ſo rich, what iſt tro that hee makes me a Stranger for? hum, I hope he has not ſo much wit to apprehend that I cozned him, he decaues me then? good heauen, who would haue thought, it would euer haue come to this paſſe, —yet hee's a proper Gentleman ifaith, giue him his due—marry thats his Morgage, but that I nere meane to giue him, ile make him rich inough in words if that be good, and if it come to a peece of mony I will not greatly ſticke fort, there may be hope ſome of the widdowes lands too, may one day fall vpon me if things be carried wiſely: now ſir, where is he?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: He deſires your worſhip to hold him excuſde, he has ſuch weighty Buſines it commands him wholy from all men.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Were thoſe my Nephewes words?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes indeed ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: When men grow rich they grow proud too, I perceiue that, he would not haue ſent me ſuch an anſwere once within this tweluemonth, ſee what tis when a mans come to his lands, returne to him agen ſir, tell him his Vncle deſires his company for an hower▪ Ile trouble him but an hower ſay, tis for his owne good tell him, and do you heare ſir, put worſhip vpon him, go too, doe as I bid you, he's like to be a Gentleman of worſhip very ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This is good ſport ifaith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Troth he vſes his Vncle, diſcourteouſly now, can he tell what I may do for him, Goodnes may come frō me in a minute that comes not in Seauen yeare agen, hee knowes my humour I am not ſo vſually good, tis no ſmall thing that drawes kindnes frō me, he may know that, and he will; the cheife cauſe that inuites me to do him moſt good, is the ſuddaine aſtoniſhing of
ould Hoord my Aduerſary, how pale his malice will looke at my Nephewes Aduancement, with what a deiected Spirit hee will behold his Fortunes, whome but laſt day, hee proclaymde Riotter, Penurious Make-ſhift, diſpiſed Brothell Maiſter; ha, ha, twill doe me more ſecret Ioy then my laſt purchaſſe, more pretious comfott then all theſe widdowes Reuennewes,— Now Sir. —

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: With much entrety he's at length come ſir,

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.p: Oh Nephew, let me ſalute you ſir, your welcome Nephew

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vncle I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yaue a ſault Nephew, your a Stranger here, well Heauen giue you ioy.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.p: Of what Sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hah, we can heare.
You might haue knowne your Vncles houſe ifaith, you and your widdow, go too, you were too blame; If I may tell you ſo without offence.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.p: How could you heare of that ſir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh pardon me,
It was your will to haue it kept from me I perceiue now.

sp.speaker: Ʋ Ʋit.
sp.p: Not for any defect of Loue I proteſt Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh twas Vnkindnes Nephew, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: I am ſory you take it in that ſence ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Puh, you cannot coulour it ifaith Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you but heare what I can ſay in my iuſt excuſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes faith will I, and welcome.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You that know my danger ith Citty ſir ſo well, how great my debts are, and how extreame my Creditors could not out of your pure iudgment ſir, haue wiſht vs hether.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Maſſe a firme reaſon indeed,

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Elſe my Vncles houſe, why tad beene the onely make— Match.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay and thy credit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My credit? nay my countenance, puſh, nay I know vncle you would haue wrought it ſo by your wit you would haue made her beleeue in time the whole houſe had beene mine —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I and moſt of the goods too —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: La you there; wel, let e'm al prate what they will ther's nothing like the bringing of a widdow to ones Vncles houſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay let Nephewes be rulde as they liſt, they ſhall finde their Vncles houſe, the moſt naturall place when all's done.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: There they may be bold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Life, they may do any thing there man, and feare neither Beadle nor Somner, an Vncles houſe! a very coale-harbour? Sirra, Ile touch thee neere now, haſt thou ſo much intereſt in thy widdow, that by a token thou couldſt preſently ſend for her?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth I thinke I can vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go too, let me ſee that?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Pray command one of your men hether Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: George?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Attend my Nephew? I loue a life to prattle with a rich widdow, tis prety me thinkes when our tongues goe togither, and then to promiſe much and performe little; I loue that ſport a life yfaith, yet I am in the moode now to do my Nephew ſome good, if he take me handſomely: what haue you diſpacht?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I ha ſent ſir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yet I muſt condemne you of vnkindneſſe Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heauen forbid Vncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes fayth muſt I; ſay your debts bee many, your creditors importunate, yet the kindneſſe of a thing is all Nephew, you might haue ſent me cloſe word on't, without the leaſt danger, or praeiudice to your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth I confeſſe it Vncle, I was too blame there, but indeed my intent was to haue clapt it vp ſuddainely, and ſo haue broke forth like a ioye to my friends, and a wonder to the world, beſide there's a trifle of a forty pound matter towarde the ſetting of mee forth, my friends ſhould nere haue knowne on't, I meant to make ſhift for that my ſelfe▪

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How Nephew? let me not heare ſuch a word agen, I beſeech you,—ſhall I be beholding to you?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To me alaſſe, what do you meane Vncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I charge you vpon my loue: you trouble no body but my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Y'aue no reaſon for that Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Troth Ile nere bee friends with you while you liue and you doe.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Nay and you ſay ſo Vncle, here's my hand, I will not doote —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why well ſayde, there's ſome hope in thee when thou wilt bee rulde, ile make it vp fifty fayth, becauſe I ſee thee ſo reclaimde; peace, here comes my wife with Sam her tother huſbands Sonne.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Good Aunt—

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Couzē Wit-good? I reioyce in my ſalute, your moſt welcome to this Noble Citty gouern'd with the ſword in the Scabbard,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And the wit in the pommell, good Maiſter Sam fredome I returne the ſalute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: By the maſſe ſhe's comming wife, let mee ſee now how thou wilt entertaine her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I hope I am not to learne ſir, to entertaine a widdowe, tis not ſo long ago ſince I was one my ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shee's come indeed?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My Vncle was deſirous to ſee you widdow, and I praeſum'd to enuite you.

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.p: The praeſumption was nothing Maiſter Wit-good, is this yours Vncle ſir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Marry am I ſweete widdow, and his good Vncle he ſhal finde me, I by this ſmack that I giue thee, thou'rt welcome, wife, bid the widdow welcome the ſame way agen.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I am a Gentleman now too, by my fathers occupation, and I ſee no reaſon but I may kiſſe a widdowe by my Fathers Coppy, truely I thinke the Charter is not againſt it, ſurely theſe are the wordes, the Sonne once a Gentleman, may reuell it, tho his father were a dauber, tis about the 15 page,—ile to her—

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Y'are not very buſie now, a worde with thee ſweete widdow—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Coades-Nigs, I was neuer ſo diſgrac'ſt, ſince the houre my mother whipt me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Beſide, I haue no childe of mine owne to care for, ſhee's my ſecond wife, old, paſt bearing, clap ſure to him widdow, he's like to be my heire I can tell you?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is he ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hee knowes it already and the knaues proud on't, iolly rich widdowes haue beene offerd him here ith Citty, great marchants wiues, and do you thinke he would once looke vpon e'm? forſooth heele none, you are beholding to him ith Coūtry then; ere we could be, nay, ile hold a wager widdow if hee were once knowne to bee in towne, hee would bee preſently ſought after, nay and happie were they, that could catch him firſt.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I thinke ſo?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh, there would be ſuch running to and fro widdow, hee ſhould not paſſe the ſtreetes for e'm: he'ed bee tooke vp in one great houſe or other preſently, fah, they know he has it & muſt haue it; you ſee this houſe here widdowe, this houſe and all comes to him, goodly Roomes ready furniſht, ſeeld with plaſter of paris, and all hung aboue with cloth of arras. Nephew!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Sir —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shew the widdowe your houſe, carry her into all the Roomes, and bid her welcome,—you ſhall ſee widdow—Nephew?—ſtrike all ſure aboue and thou bee'ſt a good boye—ah—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alaſſe ſir, I know not how ſhee would take it:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The right way I warrant tee, a poxe, art an aſſe, would I were in thy ſtead, get you vp, I am a ſhamde of you, ſo: let e'm agree as they wil now? many a match has beene ſtruck vp in my houſe a this faſhion, let e'm try all manner of waies ſtill there's nothing like an Vncles houſe to ſtrike the ſtroake in, —Ile hold my wife in talke a little, now Ginnee; your ſonne there goes a wooing to a poore Gentlewoman but of a 1000. portion, ſee my Nephew, a lad of leſſe hope, ſtrikes at foure hundred a yeare in good Rubbiſh▪

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Well we muſt do as we may ſir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p:
Ile haue his money ready told for him, againe hee come downe, let mee ſee too, by'th maſſe I muſt preſent the widdowe with ſome Iewell, a good peece a plate or ſuch a deuice, twill
harten her on wel, I haue a very faire ſtranding cup, and a good hie ſtanding cup wil pleaſe a widow aboue al other peices.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Do you mock vs with your Nephew, I haue a plot in my head ſonne, ifaith huſband to croſſe you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is it a tragedy plot, or a comedy plot, good mother.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Tis a plot ſhall vexe him, I charge you of my bleſſing Sonne Sam, that you preſently withdrawe the Action of your loue from Maiſter Hoords Neece.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How mother.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Nay I haue a plot in my head ifaith, here take this chain of gold and this faire diamond, dogge me the widdow home to her lodging, and at thy beſt opportunity faſten e'm both vpon her—nay I haue a Reach, I can tell you thou art knowne what thou art ſonne among the right worſhipfull; all the twelue companyes.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Truely I thanke 'em for it.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: He, he's a ſcab to thee, and ſo certifie her, thou haſt two hundred a yeare of thy ſelfe, beſide thy good parts— a proper perſon and a louely, if I were a widdow I could find in my heart to haue thee my ſelfe, ſonne, I, from em all.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thanke you for your good will mother, but in deed I had rather haue a Stranger: and if I wo her not in that Violent faſhion, that I will make her bee glad to take theſe gifts ere I leaue her, let me neuer be called the heire of your body.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Nay I know theres inough in you ſonne if you once come to put it forth.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ile quickly make a Bolt, or a ſhaft ont.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Faith Maiſter Hoord, I haue beſtowde many months in the Suite of your Neece, ſuch was the deere loue I euer bore to her vertues, but ſince ſhe hath ſo extreamely denied me, I am to lay out for my fortunes elſe where.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Heauen forbid but you ſhould fir, I euer told you my Neece, ſtood otherwiſe affected.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe you did ſir, yet in regard of my great loſſe of time, and the zeale with which I ſought your Neece, ſhall I deſire one fauour of your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: In regard of thoſe two tis hard but you ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I ſhall reſt gratefull, tis not full 3. houres ſir, ſince the happy rumour of a rich Country widdow came to my hearing.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How a rich Country widdow?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Foure hundred a yeare landed.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Yea?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Moſt firme ſir, and I haue learnt her lodging, here my ſuite begins ſir, if I might but entreate your worſhip to bee a countenance for mee, and ſpeake a good word: for your words will paſſe, I nothing doubt, but I might ſet faire for the widdowe, nor ſhall your labour ſir end altogither in thankes, two hundred Angells—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: So, ſo, what ſuiters has ſhee?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There lies the comfort ſir, the report of her is yet but a whiſper, and onely ſollicited by young Riotous Wit-good, Nephew to your mortall aduerſary.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ha? art certaine he's her ſuiter?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Moſt certaine ſir, and his Vncle very induſtrious to beguile the widdow, and make vp the match!

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: So? very good?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now ſir you know this yong Wit-good is a ſpend-thrift— diſſolute fellow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A very Raſkall:

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A mid-night ſurfetter.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: The ſpume of a Brothel-houſe.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: True ſir? which beeing well told in your worſhippes phraze, may both heaue him out of her minde, and driue a faire way for me to the widdowes affections.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Attend me about 5.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: With my beſt care ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Foole thou haſt left thy treaſure with a theefe, to truſt a widdower with a ſuite in loue, happy reuenge I hug thee, I haue not onely the meanes layde before me, extreamely to croſſe my aduerſary, and confound the laſt hopes of his Nephew, but therby to enrich my ſtate; augment my reuennewes, and build mine owne fortunes greater, ha, ha.
Ile marre your phraze, ore-turne your flatteries,
Vndo your windings, policies, and plots,
Fall like a ſecret and diſpatchfull plauge on your ſecured comforts, why I am able to buy 3. of Lucer, thrice out-bid him, let my out-monies be reckond and all.

sp.p: I am glad of this newes.
So are we by my faith.
Yong Wit-good will be a gallant agen now.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Peace?
I promiſe you Maiſter Cock-pit ſhe's a mighty rich widdow.
Why haue you euer heard of her.
Who widdow Medler, ſhee lies open to much rumour.
Foure hundred a yeare they ſay in very good land.
Nay tak't of my word if you beleeue that, you beleeue the leaſt.
And to ſee how cloſſe hee keepes it.
Oh ſir there's policy in that to preuent better ſuiters.
Hee owes me a hundred pound, and I proteſt I neere lookte for a pennie.
He little dreames of our comming, heele wonder to ſee his creditors vpon him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Good, his creditors, ile follow, this makes for mee, all know the widdowes wealth & tis well knowne, I can eſtate her fairely, I and will.
In this one chance ſhines a twice happy Fate,
I both deiect my foe, and raiſe my ſtate.

div.head: Incipit ACT. 3.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Why alaſſe, my Creditors? could you finde no other time to vndo mee but now, rather your malice appeares in this then the iuſtneſſe of the debt.
Maiſter Wit-good I haue forborne my money long.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I pray ſpeake lowe ſir, what do you meane?
We heare you are to be married ſuddainely to a rich Country widdow?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
What can bee kept ſo cloſſe but you creditors here on't, wel, tis a lamentable ſtate, that our cheifeſt afflicters ſhould firſt
heare of our fortunes, why this is no good courſe yfaith ſirs, if euer you haue hope to bee ſatiſfied, why doe you ſeeke to confound the meanes that ſhould worke it, there's neither piety, no nor policy in that, ſhine fauorably now, why I may rize and ſpred agen, to your great comforts.
He ſaies true yfaith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Remoue me now, and I conſume for euer.
Sweete Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How can it thriue which from the Sun you ſeuer.
It cannot indeed?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh then ſhow patience, I ſhall haue ynough to ſatiſfie you all.
I, if we could be content a ſhame take vs.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: For looke you, I am but newly ſure yet to the widdow, & what a Rend might this diſcredit make: within theſe 3. daies will I binde you lands for your ſecurities.

sp.l: No, good Maiſter Wit-good,
Would twere as much as we dare truſt you with?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know you haue beene kinde, how euer now either by wrong report, or falſe incitement your gentleneſſe is iniurde, in ſuch a ſtate as this a man cannot want foes.
sp.l: If on the ſuddaine he begin to rize,
No man that liues can count his enimyes.
You had ſome intelligence I warrant yee, from an ill-willer.

sp.p: Faith wee heard you brought vp a rich widdow ſir, and were ſuddainely to marry her.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I, why there it was, I knew twas ſo, but ſince you are ſo wel reſolude of my faith toward you, let me be ſo much fauor'd of you, I beſeech you all —

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh, it ſhall not need ifaith ſir, —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: As to lie ſtill a while, and bury my debts in ſilence, till I be fully poſſeſt of the widdow, for the truth is, I may tell you as my friends —

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh—o—o—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I am to raiſe a little money in the Citty, toward the ſetting forth of my ſelfe, for mine owne credit, and your comfort, now if my former debts ſhould be diuulg'd, all hope of my proceedings were quite extinguiſht!

Do you heare ſir, I may deſerue your cuſtome heereafter, pray let my money be accepted before a ſtrangers, here's fortie
pound I receiu'd as I came to you, if that may ſtand you in any ſtead make vſe on't, nay pray ſir, tis at your ſeruice —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You doe ſo rauiſh mee with kindneſſe, that I'me conſtrainde, to play the maide and take it?
Let none of them ſee it I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Fah—
I hope I ſhall be firſt in your remembrance after the marriage rites.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Beleeue it firmely.
So, what do you walke ſirs?
I goe—take no care ſir for money to furniſh you, within this houre ile ſend you ſufficient: come Maiſter Cock-pit wee both ſtay for you.

I ha loſt a ring ifaith, ile followe you preſently—but you ſhall finde it ſir, I know your youth and expences haue diſfurniſht you of all Iewells, ther's a Ruby of twenty pound price ſir, beſtowe it vpon your widdow, —what man, twill call vp her bloud to you, beſide if I might ſo much worke with you, I would not haue you beholding to thoſe bloud-ſuckers for any money.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Not I beleeue it.
The'ar a brace of cut-throates?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know e'm.
Send a note of all your wants to my ſhoppe and ile ſuply you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Say you ſo, why here's my hand then no man liuing ſhal do't but thy ſelfe.
Shall I carry it away from e'm both then.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I faith ſhalt thou?
Troth then I thanke you ſir.

sp.speaker: Wit▪
sp.p: Welcome good maiſter Cock-pit!

ha, ha, ha? why is not this better now, then lying a bed, I perceiue there's nothing coniures vp wit ſooner then pouerty, and nothing laies it downe ſooner then wealth and lecherie? this has ſome ſauour yet, oh that I had the morgage from mine Vncle as ſure in poſſeſſion as theſe trifles, I would forſweare Brothel at noone day, and Muſcadine and eggs at midnight.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Maiſter Wit-good? where are you?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Holla.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Rich Newes!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Would twere all in Plate,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: There's ſome in chaines and Iewells, I am ſo haunted with ſhuters Maiſter Wit-good, I know not which to diſpatch firſt.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You haue the better tearme by my faith

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Among the number, one Maiſter Hoord an Antient Gentleman.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.p: Vpon my life my Vncles aduerſary.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: It may well hold ſo, for he rayles on you,
Speakes ſhamefully of him.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.p: As I could wiſh it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I firſt denyed him, but ſo cunningly,
It rather promiſde him aſſured hopes,
Then any loſſe of labour.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Excellent,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I expect him euery hower, with Gentlemen,
With whome he labours to make good his words,
To approue you Riotous, your ſtate conſumde, your Vncle,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Wench, make vp thy owne fortunes now, do thy ſelfe a good turne once in thy Dayes, hees rich in money, moueables, and lands, —marry him, he's an old doting foole, and thats worth all, marry him, twould bee a great comfort to me to ſee thee do well ifaith, —marry him, twould eaſe my conſcience well to ſee thee well deſtowd, I haue a care of thee ifaith.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Thankes ſweete maiſter Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I reach at farder happines; firſt I am ſure it can be no harme to thee, and there may happen goodnes to me by it, proſecute it well, lets ſend vp for out witts, now we require their beſt and moſt pregnant Aſſiſtance!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Step in, I thinke I heare e'm.

div.stage: Enter Hoord and Gentlemen with the Hoſt,—ſeruingman.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Art thou the widdowes man, by my faith ſh' as a company of proper men then.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I am the worſt of ſixe ſir, good inough for blew-coates.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Harke hether, I heare ſay thou art in moſt credit with her.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Not ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Come, come, thou'rt modeſt, theres a Brace of royalls, prethee helpe me to'th ſpeech of her.

sp.speaker: Hoſ.
sp.p: Ile do what I may ſir alwayes ſauing my ſelfe harmeleſſe.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Go too do't I ſay, thou ſhalt heare better from me.

sp.speaker: Hoſ.
sp.p: Is not this a better place then 5. Marke a yeare ſtanding wages; ſay a man had but 3. ſuch clients in a day, me thinkes he might make a poore liuing ont, beſide I was neuer brought vp with ſo little honeſty, to refuſe any mans mony neuer; what g • lles there are a this ſide the world, now knowe I the widdowes minde, none but my yong maſter comes in her clutches, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Now my deere Gentlemen ſtand firmely to me, you know his follyes, and my worth.
Wee doo ſir.
But Maiſter Hoord, are you ſure he is not ith houſe now?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: vpon my honeſty▪ I choſe this time,
A purpoſe, fit, the ſpend-thrift is abroad,
Aſſiſt me: here ſhe comes▪ now my ſweete widdow,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Y are wellcome Maiſter Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Diſpatch, ſweet Gentlemen, diſpatch,
I am come widdow, to proue thoſe my words,
Neither of enuy Sprung nor of falſe tongs,
But ſuch as their deſar • s and Actions,
Doe merit and bring forth, all which theſe Gentlemen well knowne and better reputted will confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
How my affections may diſpoſe of me,
But ſurely if they find him ſo deſartleſſe,
Theyle haue that reaſon to with-draw them-ſelues.
And therefore Gentlemen I doe entreat you,
As you are faire in Reputation,
And in appearing forme ſo ſhine in truth;
I am a widdow and alaſſe you knowe,
Soone ouerthowen, tis a very ſmall thing,
That we with-ſtand, our weakenes is ſo great,
Be partiall vnto neither, but deliuer,
Without affection your opinion,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And that will driue it home,

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: Nay I beſecch your ſilence Maiſter Hoord,
You are a party.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Widdow? not a word!

sp.l: The better firſt to worke you to beleife,
Know neither of vs owe him flattery,
Nor tother malice, but vnbribed cenſure,
So helpe vs our beſt fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It ſuffizes?

sp.l: That Wit-good is a riotous vndon man,
Imperfect both in fame and in eſtate:
His debts welthier then he, and executions
In waite for his due body, we'ele maintayne
With our beſt credit, and our deereſt bloud.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Nor land, nor liuing ſay you, pray take heede you do not wrong the Gentleman?

sp.l: What we ſpeake,
Our liues and meanes are ready to make good.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Alaſſe, how ſoone are wee poore ſoules beguild!
And for his Vncle.—

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let that come to me,
His Vncle a ſeuere extortioner,
A Tyrant at a forfeiture, greedy of others miſeries,
One that would vndo his brother; nay ſwallowe
Vp his father, if he can
Within the fadomes of his conſcience.
Nay beleeue it widdow,
You had not onely matcht your ſelfe to wants,
But in an euill and vnnaturall ſtocke.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Follow hard, Gentlemen, follow hard?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Is my loue ſo deceau'd, before you all
I do renounce him, on my knees I vow
He nere ſhall marry mee,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heauen knowes hee neuer meant it?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: There, take her at the bound,—

sp.l: Then with a new and pure affection,
Behold you Gentleman, graue, kinde and rich:
A match worthy your ſelfe, eſteeming him,
You do regard your ſtate.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ile make her a ioynture ſay.
Hee can ioyne land to land, and will poſſeſſe you of what you can deſire.
Come widdow come.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: The world is ſo deceitfull?

sp.l: There tis deceitfull,
Where flattery, want, and imperfection lies:
But none of theſe in him? puſh —

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Pray ſir.
Come you widdowes are euer moſt back-ward, when you ſhould doe your ſelues moſt good, but were it to marry a chin not worth a haire now, then you would bee forward ynough? come, clap hands, a match.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Withall my heart widdow, thankes Gentlemen,
I will deſerue your labour, and thy loue.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alaſſe, you loue not widdowes but for wealth,
I promiſe you I ha nothing ſir,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Well ſaid, widdowe, well ſaid, thy Loue is all I ſeeke, before theſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Now I muſt hope the beſt,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: My ioyes are ſuch they want to be expreſt,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But Maiſter Hoord, one thing I muſ • remember you of before theſe gentlemen your friends, how ſhall I ſuddainly auoyde the loathed Solleciting of that periurd Wit-good, and his Tedious—diſſembling Vncle, who this very uery day hath appointed a meeting for the ſame purpoſe too, where had not truth come forth I had beene vndon, vtterly vndon.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: What thinke you of that Gentlemen.
Twas well deuized.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Harke thee widdow, trayne out yong Wit-good ſingle, haſten him thether with thee, ſomewhat before the hower where at the place appointed theſe Gentlemen and my ſelfe wil waite the opportunty, when by ſome ſlieght remouing him from thee we'le ſuddenly enter and ſurpriſe thee, carry thee away by boate to Coale-harbour, haue a Prieſt ready and there Clap it vp inſtantly, how lik'ſt it widdow?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: In that it pleaſeth you, it likes me well.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Ile kiſſe thee for thoſe words, come▪ Gentlemen,
Still muſt I liue a Suiter to your fauours,
Still to your aide beholding.
We're engade ſir.
Tis for our credits now to ſee't well ended.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Tis for your honors Gentlemen; nay looke toote,
Not onely in ioy, but I in wealth excell,
No more ſweet widdow, but ſweete wife, farwell.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Farwell ſir.—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Oh for more ſcope, I could laugh eternally,

Giue you ioye Miſtres Hoord, I promiſe your fortune was good forſooth, y'aue fell vpon wealth ynough, and there's young Gentlemen enow can helpe you to the reſt; now it requires our wits: carry thy ſelfe but heedfully now, and wee are both—

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Maiſter Wit-good your Vncle—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Cuds me, remoue thy ſelfe a while, ile ſerue for him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nephew, good morrow, Nephew?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: The ſame to you kinde Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How fares the widdow, do's the meeting hold?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh no queſtion of that ſir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ile ſtrike the ſtroake then for thee, no more daies.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: The ſooner the better Vncle, oh ſhee's mightily followed, —

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: And yet ſo little rumourd.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Mightily? here comes one old Gentleman, and heele make her a ioynture of three hundred a yeare forſooth, another welthy ſuiter wil eſtate his ſonne in his life time, and make him weigh downe the widdow, here a Merchants ſonne wil poſſeſſe, her with no leſſe then three goodly Lordſhips at once, which were all pawnes to his Father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Peace Nephew let mee heare no more of e'm, it mads mee, thou ſhalt preuent e'm all, no words to the widdow of my comming hether, let mee ſee, tis now vpon nine, before twelue. Nephew we will haue the bargaine ſtruck, wee will faith boye.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh my pretious Vncle.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Neece, ſweete Neece, prethee haue a care to my houſe, I leaue al to thy diſcretion, be content to dreame a while, ile haue a huſband for thee ſhortly, put that care vpon me wench, for in chooſing wiues and huſbands I am onely fortunate, I haue that gift giuen me.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: But tis not likely you ſhould chuſe for me,
Since Nephew to your cheifeſt enimy:
Is he whome I affect, but oh forgetfull,
Why doſt thou flatter thy affections ſo:
With name of him, that for a widdowes bed,
Neglects thy purer loue, can in be ſo?
Or do's report diſſemble: how now ſir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A letter with which came a priuate charge.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Therein I thanke your care—I knowe this hard,

body.p: Deerer then ſight, what the world reports of me yet beleeue not, rumour will alter ſhortly, be thou conſtant, I am ſtill the ſame that I was in loue, and I hope to be the ſame in fortunes.

sp.l: I am reſolude, no more ſhall feare or doubt,
Raiſe their pale powers to keepe affection out.

div.stage: Enter with a Drawer, Hoord, and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: You're very welcome Gentlemen, Dick ſhowe thoſe Gentlemen the Pomgranite there,—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Hiſt—

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Vp thoſe ſtaires Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Piſt Drawer,—

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Anon ſir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Prethe aske at the Bar, if a gentlewomā came not in lately?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: William at the Bar did you ſee any Gentlewoman come in lately, ſpeake you I, ſpeake you no.

sp.speaker: VVithin.
sp.p: No, none came in yet but miſtres Florence.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Hee ſaies none came in yet ſir, but one Miſtres Florence.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What is that Florence? a widdow!

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Yes a duch widdow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Thats an Engliſh drab ſir, giue your worſhip good morrow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A merry knaue ifaith, I ſhall remember a dutch widdow the longeſt day of my life.
Did not I vſe moſt art to win the widdow.
You ſhall pardon mee for that ſir, Maiſter Hoord knowes I tooke her at beſt vantage.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What's that ſweete Gentlemen, what's that?
He will needs beare me downe that his art onely, wrought with the widdow moſt.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Oh you did both well Gentlemen, you did both well, I thanke you.
I was the firſt that mou'd her.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: You were ifaith.
But it was I that tooke her at the bound.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I, that was you, faith Gentlemen, tis right.
I boaſted leaſt, but twas I ioynd their hands,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: By'th maſſe I thinke hee did, you did all well gentlemen, you did al wel, contend no more:
Come you roomes fitteſt:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: True tis next the doore?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Your verie welcome, pleaſe you to walke vp ſtai • s cloths layde ſir.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Vp ſtaires! troth I am weary Maiſter Wit-good

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Reſt your ſelfe here a while widdowe, wee'le haue a cup of Muſcadine in this little Roome.

sp.speaker: Dra
sp.p: A cup of Muſcadine, you ſhall haue the beſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But do you heare ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Do you call, anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What is there prouided for dinner

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I cannot readily tell you ſir, if you pleaſe, you may goe into the kitchin and ſee your ſelfe ſir, many Gentlemen of worſhip do vſe to do it, I aſſure you ſir?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: A prety familiar Priggin raſkall, hee has his part without booke?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Againſt you are ready to drinck to mee, widdow, ile bee preſent to pledge you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Nay I commend your care, tis donne well of you? aſſe what haue I forgot.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: What Miſtres?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I ſlipt my wedding Ring off when I waſht, and left it at my lodging, prethee run, I ſhall be ſad without it, ſo, hee's gon!—boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon forſooth?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come hether ſirrah, learne ſecretly if one Maiſter Hoord an antient Gentleman be about houſe?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I heard ſuch a one nam'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I bee do thy commendations?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh you come well: away, to boate, be gon.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Thus wiſemen are reueng'd giue two for one.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I muſt requeſt you ſir, to ſhow extraordinary care, my Vncle comes with Gentlemen his friends, and tis vpon a making?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Is it ſo?
Ile giue a ſpetiall charge good Maiſter Wit-good, may I be bold to ſee her?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Who he widdow?
Withall my heart ifayth, ile bring you to her?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: If ſhee bee a Staffordſheere Gentlewoman, tis much if I know her not, —

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How now, boy, drawer.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Hie?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Do you ca • l ſir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Went the Gentlewoman vp that was here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Vp ſir? ſhe went out ſir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Out ſir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Out ſir: one Maiſter Hoord with a guard of Gentlemen carried her out at backdoore, a pretie while ſince ſir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Hoord, death and darkeneſſe, Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: The deuill of ring I can finde?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How now, what newes, where's the widdow?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: My Miſtris? is ſhe not here ſir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: More madnes yet.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Shee ſent me for a Ring.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: A plot, a plot: to Boate ſhee's ſtole away.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Follow, enquire, old Hoord my Vncles Aduerſary—

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Nephew, what's that?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Thrice miſerable wretch.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: The widdow's borne away ſir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Ha, paſſion of me, a heauy welcome Gentlemen.
The widdow gon?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who durſt attempt it?

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.p: Who but old Hoord, my Vncles aduerſary?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.p: With his confederates.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hoord, my deadly enimy, Gentlemen ſtand to me,
I will not beare it, 'tis in hate of me,
That villaine ſeekes my ſhame, nay thrifts my bloud, hee owes me mortall malice,
Ile ſpend my wealth on this deſpitefull plot,
Ere he ſhall croſſe me and my Nephew thus.

sp.speaker: Ʋ Ʋit.
sp.p: So malitiouſlie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How now you treacherous Raſcall?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That's none of my name ſir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Poore ſoule he knew not on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ime ſory, I ſee then 'twas a meere plot.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I trac'de e'm neerely.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: And heare for certaine, they haue tooke Cole-harbor.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Diuils Sanctuary,
They ſhall not reſt, Ile pluck her from his armes,
Kind & deere Gentlemen, if euer I had ſeat within your breſts—
No more good ſir, it is a wrong to vs,
To ſee you iniur'd in a cauſe ſo iuſt:
Weele ſpend our liues, but we will right our friends,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Honeſt, and kind, come, we haue delayd to long,
Nephew take comfort; a Iuſt cauſe is ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Thats all my comfort Vncle, ha, ha, ha.
Now may euents fall luckily, and well,
He that nere ſtriues, ſayes wit ſhall nere excell.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: When did I ſay my prayers? In Anno 88. when the great Armado was comming, and In Anno. 99. when the great Thundring and Lighting was I prayd heartily then ifaith, to ouerthrow Poouyes new buildings, I kneeld by my great iron cheſt I remember.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Maiſter Dampit, one may heare you, before they ſee you, you keepe ſweet howers Maiſter Dampit, we were all a bed 3 howers agoe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh yare a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So I am ifaith, and a fine Scholler, do you vſe to goe to bed Bed, ſo earely Audry?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Call you this earely Maiſter Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why iſt not one of Clocke ith morning is not that earely inough? fetch me a glaſſe of freſh-Beere.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Here, I haue warmd your Nightcap for you maiſter Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Draw it on then—I am very weake truely, I haue not eaten ſo much as the bulke of an Egge theſe 3. dayes.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You haue drunke the more Maiſter Dampit,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You mought, and you would Maiſter Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I anſwer you I cannot, hold your prating, you prat too much, and vnderſtand too litle, are you anſwered, —giue me a glaſſe of beare.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: May I aske you how you doe Maiſter Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: How do I? ifaith naught.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I nere knenw you do otherwiſe,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I eate not one pennort of bread theſe 2. yeares, giue me a glaſſe of freſh beere,—I am not ſicke, nor I am not well.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Take ths warme Napken about your necke ſir, whilſt I helpe to make you vnready.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: How now Audrie-prater, with your skiruy deuices, what ſay you now?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: What ſay I Maiſter Dampit? I ſay nothing but that you are very weake,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Faith thou haſt more cunny catching deuices then all London?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Why Maiſter Dampit I neuer deceiu▪d you in al my life?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: VVhy was that? becauſe I neuer did truſt thee.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: I care not what you ſay Maiſter Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hold thy prating, I anſwere thee, thou art a beggar, a queane, and a bawde: are you anſwerd.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Fie Maiſter Dampit, a Gentleman and haue ſuch words.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: VVhy thou baſe drudge of infortunity, thou kitchin-ſtuffe drab of Beggery, Roguery & cockſcombre, thou Cauerneſed queane of foolery, knauery and baudreaminy, ile tell thee what, I will not giue a lowſe for thy fortunes:

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: No, maiſter Dampit, and there's a Gentleman comes a wooing to me, and he doubts nothing but that you will get mee from him:

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: I, if I would either haue thee or lie with thee for two thouſand pound, would I might bee dambd, why thou baſe impudent queane of foolery, flattery, and cockſcombry, are you anſwerd?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Come will you riſe and goe to bed ſir?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Riſe, and go to bed too Audry? how do's Miſters Proſerpine?

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: Fooh—

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: She's as fine a Philoſipher of a ſtinkards wife, as any within the liberties,—fah, fah Audry:

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: How now Maiſter Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie vpon't, what a choiſe of ſtinckes here is, what haſt thou don Audry fie vppon't, here's a choice of ſtinckes indeed; giue me a glaſſe of freſh Beere, and then I wil to bed:

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: It waites for you aboue ſir?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Foh, I thinke they burne hornes in Barnards Inne, if euer I ſmelt ſuch an abhominable ſtinck, vſury forſake me:

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: They be the ſtincking nailes of his trampling feete, and he talkes of burning of hornes:

div.head: Incipit ACT. 4.
div.stage: Enter at Cole-harbour, Hoord, the VViddow and Gentlemen, he married now.

sp.l: Ioyne hearts, ioyne hands, In wedlocks bands,
Neuer to part, till death cleaue your heart,
You ſhall forſake all other women,
You Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, and Yeomen.
What my tongue ſlips, make vp with your lips.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.l: Giue you ioy Miſtreſſe Hoord, let the kiſſe come about,
Who knocks? conuay my little Pig-eater out.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hoord?

sp.speaker: Hoor,
sp.p: Vpon my life, my aduerſary, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hoord, open the doore, or we will force it ope,
Giue vs the widdow.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Gentlemen keepe'm out.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Hee comes vpon his death that enters here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My friends aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Hee has aſſiſtants, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Tut, nor him, nor them, we in this action feare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shall I in peace, ſpeake one word with the widow?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Husband and Gentlemen, heare me but a word.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Freely ſweete wife.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Let him in peaceably, you know we're ſure, from any act of his.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Moſt true,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You may ſtand by and ſmile at his old weakeneſſe, let mee alone to anſwere him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Content,
Twill be good mirth ifaith, how thinke you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Good gullery?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Vpon calme conditions let him in.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All ſpite and malice—

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Heare me Maiſter Lucre, ſo you will vow a peacefull entrance with thoſe your friends and onely exercize
Calme conference with the widdow, without fury,
The paſſage ſhall receiue you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I do vow it.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Then enter and talke freely, here ſhe ſtands.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Oh Maiſter Hoord, your ſpite has wacht the houre, your excellent at vengeance Maiſter Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am the foole you laugh at, you are wiſe ſir and knowe the ſeaſons, well, come hether widdow, why is it thus!
Oh you haue done me infinite diſgrace,
And your owne credit no ſmall Iniury,
Suffer mine enimy ſo diſpitefully
To beare you from my Nephewe, oh,
I had rather halfe my ſubſtance had beene forfet, and begd by ſome ſtaru▪d Raskall.

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.l: Why what would you wiſh me do ſir?
I muſt not ouerthrow my ſtate for loue,
We haue too many preſidents for that,
From thouſands of our welthie vndon widdowes
One may deriue ſome wit; I do confeſſe,
I lou▪d your Nephew, nay I did affect him,
Againſt the minde and liking of my friend:
Beleeu'd his promiſes, lay here in hope,
Of fla • terd liuing and the boaſt of lands,
Comming to touch his wealth and ſtate indeed,
It appeares droſſe, I finde him not the man,
Imperfect, meane, ſcarce furniſht of his needes:
In words, faire Lordſhips, in performance Houills,
Can any woman loue the thing that is not?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Broke you for this?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Was it not cauſe too much?
Send to enquire his ſtate, moſt part of it,
Lay two yeares morgag'd in his Vncles hands:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why ſay it did, you might haue knowne my minde; I could haue ſoone reſtorde it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I had I but ſeene any ſuch thing perform'd why twould haue tyed my affection and contaynd me in my firſt deſires, doe you thinke ifayth, that I could twine ſuch a dry, oake as this, had promiſe in your Nephew tooke effect:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why and there's no time paſt, and rather then my aduerſary ſhould thus thw'art my hopes, I would —

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: • ut y'aue beene euer full of golden • peech,
If wordes were lands, your Nephew would bee rich.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Widdow, beleeue it I vowe by my beſt bliſſe,
Before theſe Gentlemen I will giue in
The morgage to my Nephew inſtantly,
Before I ſleepe or eate.

sp.p:
Weele pawne our credits widdow, what he ſpeakes ſhall
be performde in fullneſſe.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: Nay more I will eſtate him
In farder bleſſings, he ſhall be my heire▪
I haue no Sonne,
Ile binde my ſelfe to that condition.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: When I ſhall heare this done, I ſhall ſoone yeeld, to reaſonable tearmes.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the meane ſeaſon,
Will you proteſt before theſe Gentlemen,
To keepe your ſelfe, as you are, now at this preſent.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: I do proteſt before theſe Gentlemen,
I will be as cleere then, as I am now.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l: I do beleeue you, here's your owne honeſt ſeruant,
Ile take him along wi • h me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: He ſhall ſee all performde and bring you word.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Thats all I waite for.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What haue you finiſht Maiſter Lucre? ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: So, laugh Hoord, laugh at your poore enimy, do, the winde may turne you may be laught at too, yes marry may you ſir—ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Ha, ha ha, if euery man that ſwells in malice,
Could be reuengd as happily as I:
He would chuſe hate, and forſweare amity.
What did he ſay wife, prethee?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Faith ſpoke to eaſe his minde,—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Oh—o—o—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You know now, little to any purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: True, true, true.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: He would do mountaines now.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I, I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Y'aue ſtruck him dead Maſter Hoord.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: I and his Nephew deſperate:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: I knowte ſirs I,
Neuer did man ſo cruſh his enimy?

div.stage: Enter Lucre with Gentlemen meeting Sam Free-dome.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My ſonne in lawe,
Sam Freedome? where's my Nephew?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O man in lamentation father?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
He thumpes his breſt like a gallant Dicer that has loſt his
doublet, and ſtands in's ſhirt to do pennance:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Alaſſe poore gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I warrant, you may heare him ſigh in a ſtill euening to your houſe at Hyegate.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I prethe ſend him in.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Were it to do a greater matter, I will not ſtick with you ſir, in regard you married my Mother?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: Sweete Gentlemen cheere him vp, I will but fetch the morgage, and returne to you inſtantly.

sp.l: Weele do our beſt ſir?—ſee where he comes,
E'en ioyleſſe and regardleſſe of all forme.

sp.p: Why how Maiſter Wit-good, fie, you a firme ſcholler, and an vnderſtanding Gentleman, and giue your beſt partes to paſſion.
Come fie?

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen!—
Sorrow of mee what a ſigh was there ſir, nine ſuch widdowes are not worth it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To be borne from me by that lecher Hoord.

sp.l: That vengeance is your Vncles, being done
More in deſpite to him, then wrong to you,
But we bring comfort now,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I beſeech you Gentlemen.
Cheere thy ſelfe man, there's hope of her ifayth?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To gladſome, to be true.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Nephew what cheere? alaſſe poore Gentleman how art thou changd? call thy freſh bloud into thy cheekes agen, ſhee comes—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nothing afflicts me ſo much,
But that it is your Aduerſary, Vncle,
And meerely plotted in deſpite of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
