sp.p: I thats it mads mee, ſpites mee? ile ſpend my wealth, e're he ſhall carry her ſo, becauſe I know tis onely to ſpite me, I this is it,—here Nephew, before theſe kinde Gentlemen I deliuer in your morgage, my promiſe to the widdow, ſee tis done, be wiſe your once more Maiſter of your owne, the widdow ſhall perceiue now, you are not altogither ſuch a beggar as the world reputes you, you can make ſhift to bring her to 300. a yeare ſir.
Berlady and thats no toye ſir:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A word Nephew?
Now you may certifye the widdow?

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: You muſt conceiue it a right Nephewe now, to doe you good, I am content to do this.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know it ſir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But your owne conſcience can tell I had it deerely ynough of you?

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.p: I thats moſt certaine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Much money layde out, beſide maney a iourney to fetch the rent, I hope youle thinke on't Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I were worſe then a beaſt elſe ifayth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Although to blinde the widdow and the world I out of policy doote, yet there's a conſcience Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heaven forbid elſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: When you are full poſſeſt,
Tis nothing to returne it:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alaſſe a thing quickly done Vncle.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Well ſayd,—you know I giue it you but in truſt.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Pray let me vnderſtand you rightly, Vncle,
You giue it me but in truſt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: That is, you truſt me with it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: True, true:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But if euer I truſt you with it agen, would I might bee truſt vp for my labour.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You can all witneſſe Gentlemen, and you ſir yeoman?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: My life for yours ſir now, I know my Miſtriſſes minde to well toward your Nephew, let things be in preparation, and ile traine her hether in moſt excellent faſhion:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A good old boy,—wife Girnne?

sp.speaker: VVife,
sp.p: Whats the newes ſir?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: The wedding daies at hand, prethee ſweete wife, expreſſe thy houſwifery, thou'rt a fine Cooke I knowte, thy firſt husband married thee out of an Aldermans kitchin, go too, he raiſde thee for rayſing of paſte, what, here's none but friends, moſt of our beginnings muſt bee winckt at, Gentlemen I enuite you all to my Nephewes wedding againſt Thurſday morning:
Withall our hearts, and wee ſhall ioye to ſee your enimy ſo mockt:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: He laught at me, gentlemen, ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Hee has no conſcience, faith would laugh at them, they laugh at one another?
Who then can be ſo cruell, troth, not I,
I rather pitty now, then ought enuie,
I do conceiue ſuch ioye in mine owne happineſſe, I haue no leyſure yet, to laugh at their follies.

l.hi: Thou ſoule of my eſtate I kiſſe thee,
I miſſe lifes Comfort when I miſſe thee.
Oh neuer will we part agen,
Ʋntill I leaue the Sight of men,
We'le nere truſt conſcience of our kin,
Since Cooſenage brings that title in.

sp.p: Ile wayte theſe 7. howers but Ile ſee him caught,
Faith ſo will I.
Hang him prodigall, he's ſtript of the Widdow.
A my Troth ſhees the wiſer, ſhe has made the happier choyſe, and I wonder of what Stuffe thoſe widdowes hearts are made of, that wil marry vnfledgd Boies, before comely thrumbchind Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Newes, newes newes,
What boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Rioter is caught.
So, ſo, ſo, ſo, it warmes me at the heart, I loue a life to ſee Dogs vpon men; oh here hee comes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My laſt ioy was ſo great it tooke away the ſence of all future afflictions, what a day is here orecaſt? how ſoone a black tempeſt riſes?
Oh wee may ſpeake with you now ſir, whats become of your rich widdow, I thinke you may caſt your cap at the widdow, may you not ſir.
He a rich widdow? who a prodigall, a dayly Rioter, and a nightly vomiter, he a widow of account? he a hole ith counter.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You do well my maiſters, to tiranize ouer miſery to afflect the affl • cted, tis a cuſtome you haue here amongſt you, I would wiſh you neuer leaue it and I hope youle do as I bid you
Come, come ſir, what ſay you extempore now to your bill of a hundred pound: a ſweet debt, for froating your doublets.
Here's mine of forty,
Here's mine of fifty.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Pray ſirs▪ youle giue me Breath.
No ſir, wel'e keepe you out of breath ſtill, then we ſhall be ſure you will not run away from vs.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you but here me ſpeake?

You ſhall pardon vs for that ſir, we know you haue too faire a tong of your owne, you ouer-came vs to lately, a ſhame take you, we are like to looſe all that for want of witneſſes, wee dealt in policy then, alwaies when we ſtriue to bee moſt politique we proue moſt cocſkcombs, Non plus vltra. I perceiue by vs, were not ordaynde to thriue by wiſdome, and therefore wee muſt be content to be Tradeſ-men.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Giue me but reaſonable time, and I proteſt Ile make you ample Satiſfaction.
Do you talke of Reaſonable time to vs?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Tis true, beaſts know no reaſonable time,
Wee muſt haue either mony or carcaſſe.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alaſſe what good will my carcaſſe do you?
Oh tis a Secret delight we haue amongſt vs, we that are vſde to keepe birds in cages, haue the heart to keepe men in priſon, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I perceiue I muſt craue a litle more Ayde from my wits, do but make ſhift for me this once, and Ile forſweare euer to trouble you in the like faſhion hereafter, Ile haue better employment for you, and I liue. Youle giue me leaue my maiſters to make Tryall of my friends and raiſe all meanes I can.
Thats our deſires ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Maiſter Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh art thou come!

sp.speaker: Hoſt
sp.p: May I ſpeake one word with you in priuate ſir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No by my faith canſt thou. I am in hell here and the Deuills will not let me Come to thee.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Do you call vs diuuills, you ſhall find vs Puritanes beare him away, let em talke as they go, we'le not ſtand to heare 'em, ah ſir, am I a deuile, I ſhall thinke the better of my ſelfe as long as I liue, a Deuill ifaith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p:
What a Sweet bleſſing haſt thou Maiſter Hoord aboue a multitude, wilt thou neuer be thankeful? how doſt thou thinke to be bleſt another time? or doſt thou count this the full meaſure of thy hapines by my troth I thinke thou doeſt▪ not only a wife large in poſſeſſions, but ſpatious in content, ſhe's rich, ſhe's yong, ſhe's fayre, ſhe's wife, when I wake I thinke of her lands that reuiues me, when I go to bed, I dreame of her beauty, and
thats ynough for me, ſhe's worth 4. hundred a yeare in her very ſmock, if a man knewe how to vſe it, but the iourney will bee all introth into the Country, to ride to her Lands in ſtate and order following my Brother & other worſhipfull Gentlemen whoſe companies I ha ſent downe for already, to ride along with vs, in their goodly Decorum beards, their broad Veluet chaſhocks, and chaines of gold twice or thrice double; againſt which time, ile entertaine ſome ten men of mine own, into Liueries, all of occupations or qualities, I will not keepe an idle man about mee, the ſight of which will ſo vexe my Aduerſary Lucre, for weele paſſe by his dore of purpoſe, make a little ſtand for nonce, & haue our horſes Curuet before the window, certainly he will neuer endure it, but run vp & hang himſelf preſently? how now ſirra? what newes? any that offer their ſeruice to me yet.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes ſir, there are ſome ith hall, that waite for your worſhips liking, and deſire to be entertainde.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Are they of occupation?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They are men fit for your worſhip ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: Sayſt ſo? ſend e'm all in!—to ſee ten men ride after mee in watchet liueries with Orenge-tawny capes, twill cut his combe ifayth, how now? of what occupation are you ſir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A Taylor, an't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: A taylor, oh very good, you ſhall ſerue to make all the Liueries—what are you ſir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A Barber ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: A Barber very needefull, you ſhall ſhaue all the houſe, and if neede require ſtand for a Reaper ith Sommer time,— You ſir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: A Perfumer?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I ſmelt you before, Perſumers of all men had neede carry themſelues vprightly, for if they were once knaues they would be ſmelt out quickly, —to you ſir?

sp.speaker: Fawl.
sp.p: A Fawlkner an't pleaſe your worſhip—

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Sa ho, ſa ho, ſa ho—and you ſir?

sp.speaker: Hun.
sp.p: A Huntſman ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p:
There boy, there boye, there boye? I am not ſo old but I haue pleaſant daies to come, I promiſe you my Maiſters I take ſuch a good liking to you, that I entertaine you all, I put you already into my countenance, and you ſhall be ſhortly in my liuerie? but eſpecially you two my • olly Fawlkner, and
my bonny huntſman, wee ſhall haue moſt neede of you at my wifes Mannor-houſes ith Country, there's goodly parkes and Champion-grounds for you, we ſhall haue all our ſports within our ſelues, all the Gentlemen ath Country ſhall bee beholding to vs and our paſtimes:

sp.speaker: Faul:
sp.p: And weele make you worſhip admire ſir:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Sayſt thou • o do but make mee admire, and thou ſhalt want for nothing,—my Taylor?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Anon ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Go preſently in hand with the liueries.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: My Barber.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Here ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Make e'm all trim fellowes, lowſe e'm well, eſpecially my huntſman, and cut all their beards of the Polonian faſhion: my perfumer:

sp.speaker: Per:
sp.p: Vnder your noſe ſir:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Caſt a better ſauour vpon the knaues, to take away the ſent of my Taylors feete, and my Barbers Lotium-water:
It ſhall be carefully performde ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: But you my Faulkner and Huntſman, the welcomſt men aliue ifayth:

sp.speaker: Hun:
sp.p: And weele ſhow you that ſir, ſhall deſerue your worſhippes fauour?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I prethee ſhow mee that: goe you knaues all, and waſh your lungs ith Buttery, go—byth maſſe, and well remembred, ile aske my wife that queſtion, wife, Miſtrs Iane Hoord!

sp.speaker: Curt:
sp.p: Sir? would you with me.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I would but know ſweet wife, which might ſtād beſt to thy liking, to haue the wedding dinner kept here or ith Country?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Hum? faith ſir twould like me better here, here you were married, here let all rites be ended.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Could a Marqueſſe giue a better anſwere? Hoord beare thy head aloft, thou'ſt a wife will aduance it, what haſte comes here now? yee a letter: ſome dregge of my Aduerſaries malice: come hether, whats the newes!

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: A thing that concernes my Miſtris ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why then it concernes me knaue?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I and you knaue too, (cry your worſhippe mercy) you are both like to come into trouble I promiſe you ſir, a praecontract

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How a praecontract ſayſt thou?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I feare they haue too much proofe on't ſir, old Lucre he runs mad vp and downe and will to lawe as faſt as he can, yong Wit-good layde hold on by his creditors, hee exclaymes vpon you a tother ſide, ſaies you haue wrought his vndoing, by the iniurious detayning of his contract.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Body a me?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: He will haue vtmoſt ſatiſfaction.
The lawe ſhall giue him recompence he ſaies.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Alaſſe his creditors ſo mercileſſe, my ſtate beeing yet vncertaine, I deeme it not vnconſcionable to furder him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: True ſir—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife, what ſaies that letter let me conſtrue it.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Curſt be my raſh and vnaduiſed words,
Ile ſet my foote vpon my tongue,
And tread my inconſiderate grant to duſt.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife—

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: A prety ſhift yfaith, I commend a woman when ſhee can make away a letter from her huſband handſomely, and this was cleanely done by my troth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I did ſir?
Some fooliſh words I muſt confeſſe did paſſe,
Which, now letigiouſly he faſtens on me.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Of what force? let me ezamine e'm.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Too ſtrong I feare, would I were well free'd of him.

sp.speaker: Hoo,
sp.p: Shall I compound?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: No ſir, ide haue it done ſome Nobler way
Of your ſide; ide haue you come off with honor,
Let baſeneſſe keepe with them: why haue you not the meanes ſir, the occaſions offerd you.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Where? how? deere wife.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hee is now caught by his creditors, the ſlaue's needie, his debts petty, hee'le rather binde himſelfe, to all inconueniences then rot in pryſon, by this onely meanes you may get a releaſe from him, 'tis not yet come to his Vncles hearing, ſend ſpeedily for the creditors, by this time hee's diſperate, hee'le ſet his hand to any thing, take order for his debts, or diſcharge e'm quite, a pax on him, lets be rid of a raskall.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p:
Excellent, thou doſt aſtoniſh mee, go, runne, make haſt,
bring both the creditors and Wit-good hether.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: This will be ſome reuenge yet.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: In the meane ſpace Ile haue a releaſe drawne-within there.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Sirrah, come take derictions, goe to my Scriuener.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ime yet like thoſe, whoſe riches lie in dreames,
If I be wakte the're falſe, ſuch is my fate,
Who ventures deeper then the deſperate ſtate.
Though I haue find yet could I become new,
For where I once vow, I am euer true.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Away, Diſpatch, on my Diſpleaſure, quickly, happy occaſion, pray heauen hee bee in the right Vayne now to ſet his hand toot, that nothing alter him; grant that al his follyes may meete in him at once, to beſot him inough.
I pray for him ifaith, and here he comes;

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What would you with me now, my Vncles ſpitefull aduerſary.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Nay I am friends,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I when your miſcheifes ſpent.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I heard you were arreſted.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Wel, what then? you wil pay none of my debts I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.l: A wiſeman cannot tell,
There may be thoſe Conditions greed vpon,
May moue me to do much,

sp.speaker: VVitt.
sp.l: I when Tis thou periured Woman, O no name
Is vild inough to match thy trechery,
That art the cauſe of my confuſion.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Out you penurious ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Nay wife you are too froward,
Let him alone, giue looſers leaue to talke.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Shall I remember thee of an other promiſe far ſtronger then the firſt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ide faine knowe that.

sp.speaker: VVit.
sp.p: Twould call ſhame to thy cheeks.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Shame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Harke in your ear.—will hee come of thinkſt thou, and pay my Debts roundly.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Doubt nothing, theres a Releaſe a drawing and all to which you muſt ſet your hand.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
But mee thinkes ifaith you might haue made ſome
ſhift to diſcharge this your ſelfe, hauing in the morgage, and neuer haue burdned my conſcience with it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A my troth I could not, for my creditors cruelties extend to the preſent.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: No more,—why do your worſt for that, I defie you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Y'are impudent, ile call vp witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Call vp thy wits for thou haſt beene deuoted to follies a long time.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Wife, y'are too bitter? Maiſter Wit-good, and you my Maiſters, you ſhal heare a milde ſpeech come from me now, and this it is, tas beene my fortune, Gentlemen, to haue an extraordinary bleſſing powr'd vpon me alate, and here ſhe ſtands, I haue wedded her and bedded her, & yet ſhe is little the worſe, ſome fooliſh wordes ſhee hath paſt to you in the Country, and ſome peeuiſh debts you owe here in the Citty, ſet the Hares head to the Gooſe—giblet, releaſe you her of her words, and ile releaſe you of your debts ſir:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Would you ſo, I thanke you for that ſir, I cannot blame you ifayth.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why are not debts better then words ſir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Are not words promiſes, and are not promiſes debts ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: He plaies at back-Racket with me.
Come hether Maiſter Wit-good come hether, be rulde by fooles once:
We are Cittizens and know what belong toote.
Take hold of his offer pax on her, let her goe, if your debts were once diſcharg'd, I would helpe you to a widdow my ſelfe worth ten of her.
Maſſe partner and now you remember mee on't, there's Maiſter Muligrubs ſiſter newly falne a widdow.

Cuds mee, as pat as can be, there's a widdow left for you, ten thouſand in mony, beſide Plate, Iewells et caetera I warrant it a match, wee can do all in all with her, prethee diſpatch weele carry thee to her preſently.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My Vncle wi • l nere endure me, when he ſhall heare I ſet my hand to a releaſe:

Harke, ile tell thee a Trick for that, I haue ſpent fiue hundred pound in ſuites in my time, I ſhould be wiſe, thou it now a
priſoner, make a releaſe, takte of my worde, whatſoeuer a man makes as long as he is in durance, tis nothing in lawe, not thus much.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſir?
I haue payde for't I know't.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Proceede then, I conſent.
Why wel ſayde:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How now my Maiſters, what haue you done with him?
With much a doe ſir, we haue got him to conſent.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ah—a—a,— and what came his debts to now?
Some eight ſcore od pounds ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Nau, nau, nau, nau, naw, tell me the ſecond time, giue me a lighter ſomme, they are but deſperate debts you know, neere cald in but vpon ſuch an accident, a poore needy knaue hee would ſtarue and rot in priſon, come, come, you ſhall haue ten ſhillings in the pound and the ſomme downe roundly—
You muſt make it a marke ſir,—

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Go too then, tell your mony in the meane time, you ſhall finde little leſſe there,—come Maiſter Wit-good you are ſo vnwilling to do your ſelfe good now, welcome honeſt Scriuener, now you ſhall heare the releaſe read,—

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: Be it known, to al men by theſe preſents, that I Theodorus Wit-good, Gentleman, ſole Nephew to Pecunious Lucre, hauing vniuſtly made title and claime, to one Iane Medler, late widdow of Anthory Medler, and now wife to Walkadine Hoord, in conſideration of a competent ſom of mony to diſcharge my debts, do for euer hereafter diſclaime any title, right, eſtate, or intereſt in or to the ſayd widdow late in the occupation of the ſayd Anthony Medler, and now in the occupation of Walkadine Hoord, as alſo neither to laye claime, by vertue of any former contract, grant, promiſe or demiſe, to any of her Mannor, Mannorhouſes, Parkes, Groues, Meadow-grounds, arrable lands, Barnes, ſtacks, Stables, Doue-holes, and Cunny-borrowes, togither with al her cattell, money, plate, iewells, borders, chaines, bracelets, furnitures, hangings, moueables, or immouerables in wittneſſe wherof I the ſayd Theodorus Wit-good, haue enterchangeably ſet to my hand and ſeale before theſe preſents, the daie, & date aboue written.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What a pretious fortune haſt thou ſlipt here like a beaſt as thou art?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Come, vnwilling heart come.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: well Maiſter Hoord, giue me the pen, I ſee
Tis vaine to quarrell with our deſtiny.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Oh as vaine a thing as can bee, you cannot commit a greater abſurdity ſir,—ſo, ſo, giue mee that hand now, before al theſe preſents I am friends for euer with thee.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth, and it were pit • y of my heart now, if I ſhould beare you any grudge yfaith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Content, ile ſend for thy Vncle againſt the wedding dinner, we will be friends once agen.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I hope to bring it to paſſe my ſelfe ſir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How now? iſt right my maſters?
Tis ſomthing wanting ſir, yet it ſhall be ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why well ſayd, a good conſcience makes a fine ſhowe now a daies, come my Maiſters you ſhall all—taſt of my wine ere you depart.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We follow you ſir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ile try theſe fellowes now, —a word ſir, what will you carry me to that widdow now?

Why do you thinke we were in earneſt yfaith? carry you to a rich widdow, wee ſhould get much credit by that; a noted Rioter a contemptible prodigall, twas a Trick we haue amongſt vs, to get in our mony, fare you well ſir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Farewell and be hangd, you ſhort-pig-hayrde Ram-headed raskalls, he that beleeues in you, ſhall nere be ſau'd I warrant him, by this new league, I ſhall haue ſome acceſſe vnto my loue —

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: Maiſter Wit-good?

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: My life.

sp.speaker: Neec.
sp.p: Meete me preſently, that note directs you, I would not be ſuſpected our happineſſe attends vs, farewell?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A words ynough.

div.stage: Dampit the Vſurer in his bed, Audry ſpinning by.

lg.l: Let the Vſurer cram him, in intereſt that excell,
There's pits enow to dam him, before he comes to hell.
In Holborne, ſome: in Fleete-ſtreet ſome,
Ʋ Ʋhere ere he come, there's ſome there's ſome.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Trahe, traheto, drawe the Curtaine, giue mee a ſippe of Sack more.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Looke you, did not I tell you he lay like the deuill in chaines, when he was bound for a thouſand yeare.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: But I thinke the deuill had no ſteele Bedſtaffes, he goes beyond him for that.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay doe but marke the conceite of his drincking, one muſt wipe his mouth for him with a muckinder, do you ſee ſir.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: Is this the ſick trampler, why he is onely bed-red with drincking.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: True ſir, he ſpies vs.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What? ſir Triſtram? you come and ſee a weake man here, a very weake man,—

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: If you be weake in body, you ſhould be ſtrong in prayer ſir.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Oh, I haue pray'd too much poore man.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: There's a taſt of his ſoule for you.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: Fah, loathſome?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I come to borrow a hundred pound of you ſir.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.l: Alaſſe you come at an ill time, I cannot ſpare it ifayth,
I ha but two thouſand ith houſe.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Out you gernatiue queane, the mullipood of villany, the Spinner of concupiſcency.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yee gentlemen are you here before vs? how is hee now?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Faith the ſame man ſtill, the Tauerne bitch has bit him ith head.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Wee ſhall haue the better ſport with him, peace, and how cheeres Maiſter Dampit now?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Oh, my boſome ſir Lancelot, how cheere I? thy preſence is reſtoratiue:

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: But I heare a great complaint of you Maiſter Dampit, among gallants.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: I am glad of that ifayth; —prethee what?

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: They ſay you are waxte proud alate, and if a friend viſit you in the after-noone, you'le ſcarce know him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, proud? I cannot remember any ſuch thing, ſure I was drunck then.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Thinke you ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: There twas ifayth, nothing but the pride of the Sack and ſo certifie e'm, fetch Sack ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A vengeance Sack you once.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Why Maiſter Dampit if you hold on as you begin, and lie a little longer, you neede not take care how to diſpoſe your wealth, you'le make the Vintner your heire.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Out you babliaminy, you vnfetherd cremitoryed queane, you culliſance of ſcabiofity.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Good words Maiſter Dampit, to ſpeake before a maide and a virgin.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Hang thy virginity, vpon the pole of carnality.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Sweete tearmes, my Miſtris ſhall know e'm.

sp.speaker: Lam:
sp.p: Note but the miſery of this vſuring ſlaue, here hee lies like a noyſome dunghill, full of the poyſon of his druncken blaſphemies, and they to whome he bequeathes all, grudge him the very meate that feedes him, the very pillow that eaſes him, here may a vſurer behold his end, what profits it to be a ſlaue in this world, and a deuil ith next.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Sir Lancelot? let me buſſe thee ſir Lancelot, thou art the onely friend that I honor and reſpect.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thanke you for that Maiſter Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Farewell my boſome ſir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Gentlemen, and you loue mee, let mee ſtep behinde you, and one of you fall a talking of me to him.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Content—Maiſter Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So ſir.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Here came ſir Lancelot to ſee you e'en now.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hang him raskall.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Who ſir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pythagoricall raskall.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Pythagoricall?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I he changes his cloake when he meetes a Sergiant.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What a rogues this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I wonder you can raile at him ſir, he comes in loue to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A louſe for his loue, his father was a Combe-maker, I haue no neede of his crawling loue, hee comes to haue longer day, the ſuperlatiue raskall:

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Sfoote I can no longer endure the rogue, Maiſter Dampit, I come to take my leaue once agen ſir?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Who? my deere and kinde Sir Lancelot? the onely Gentleman of England, let me hug thee, farewell and a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Compoſde of wrongs and ſlauiſh flatteries.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, he ſhall ſhow you more Tricks yet, ile giue you another taſt of him:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I'ſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: His memory is vpon departing.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Another cup of Sack.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Maſſe then twill be quite gon: before he drinke that, tell him theres a cuntry client come vp, and here attends for his Learned aduice,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Inough.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: One Cup more, and then let the Bell toale, I hope I ſhall be weake inough by that time.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Maiſter Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Is the Sack ſpouting.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Tis comming forward ſir,—heres a countryman a client of yours, waytes for your deepe and profound aduice ſir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A cockſcombry? where is he? let him approch, ſet me vp a pegge higher.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You muſt draw nere ſir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Now good-man fooleaminy, what ſay you to me now

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Pleaſe your good worſhip, I am a poore man ſir.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What make you in my Chamber then?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I would entreate your worſhips deuice in a iuſt and honeſt cauſe ſir.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I meddle with no ſuch matters, I refer e'm, to Maiſter No-mans Office.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I had but one houſe left me in all the world ſir which was my fathers, my Grand-fathers, my great Grandfathers, and now a Villaine has vniuſtly wrung me out, and tooke poſſeſſion out.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Has he ſuch feates? thy beſt courſe is to bring thy eiectione firme, and in Seauen yeare thou mayſt ſhoue him out by the Law.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Alaſſe, ant pleaſe your worſhip, I haue ſmall friends and leſſe mony.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hoyda, this geere will fadge well, haſt no money, why then my aduice is thou muſt ſet fire ath houſe & ſo get him out.

sp.speaker: Lam
sp.p: That will breake ſtrife indeed,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thanke your worſhip for your hot Counſell ſir.— altring but my voyce alitle, you ſee he knew me not, you may obſerue by this that a drunkards memory, holds longer in the voyce then in the perſon, but Gentlemen ſhall I ſhow you a ſight, behold the litle diue-dapper of Damnation, Gulfe the vſurer, for his time worſe then tother.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: What's he comes with him?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Why Hoord, that maried lately the widdowe medler.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Oh, I cry you mercy ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Now gentlemen viſitants? how dos maiſter Dampit?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: faith here hee lies e'n drawing—in ſir, good canary as faſt as hee can ſir, a very weake creature truely, hee is almoſt paſt memory.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Fie Maiſter Dampit: you lie lazing a bed here, and I come to enuite you to my wedding dinner, vp, vp, vp.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Whoſe this maiſter Hoord! who haſt thou married in the name of foolery.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A rich widdow.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A Duch widdow.

sp.speaker: Hoo,
sp.p: A ritch widdow,—one widdow medler.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Medler ſhe keepes open houſe.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: She did I can tell you in her tother husbands dayes, open houſe for all comers, horſe and man was welcome, and Roome inough for em all.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Theres to much for thee then, thou mayſt let out ſome to thy Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: What? hung a liue in chaynes O Spectacle, bed ſtaffs of ſteele, O monſtrum, horrendum, Informe, Ingens cui Lumen ademptum, O Dampit, Dampit, heres a Iuſt iudgment, ſhowne vpon vſury, extortion, and trampling Villany.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: This exlent, theefe rayles vpon the Theefe.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Is this the end of cut throate Vſury, Brothell, and blaſphemy? now maiſt thou ſee what Race a Vſurer runnes.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why thou Rogue of vniuerſality, do not I know thee? thy Sound is like the cuckowe, the welch Embaſſador, thou cowardly ſlaue that offers to fight with a ſicke man when his weapons downe: rayle vpon me in my naked bed? why thou great Lucifers litle vicar, I am not ſo weake but I know a knaue at firſt ſight, thou Inconſcionable Raskall, thou that goeſt vpon middleſex Iuryes, and will make haſt to giue vp thy verdit, becauſe thou wilt not looſe thy dinner, are you anſwered?

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Ant twere not for ſhame.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Thou wouldſt be hangd then.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay you muſt exercize patience Maiſter Gulfe, alwayes in a ſick-mans Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: 'Heele quarrell with none I warrant you, but thoſe that are bedred.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Let him come Gentlemen, I am arm'd, reach my cloſſe ſtoole hether.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Here wilbe a ſweet fraie anon, Ile leaue you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay wel'e a long with you, Maiſter Gulfe.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Hang him vſuring raskall.

sp.speaker: Lan,
sp.p: Puſh, ſet your Strenght to his, your wit to his.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen depart, his howers come vpon him, ſleepe in my boſome, ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.l: Nay we haue inough of him ifaith, keepe him for the houſe.—Now▪ make your beſt.
For thrice his wealth, I would not haue his breſt.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: A litle thing would make me beat him, now he's aſleep.

sp.speaker: Lan
sp.l: Maſſe then twilbe a pittifull day when he wakes.
I would be loath to ſee that day, come.

sp.speaker: Lul:
sp.p: You ouer-rule me gentlemen ifaith.

div.head: ACTVS. 5.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay vncle, let me preuayle with you ſo much,
Ifaith go, now he has enuited you,

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: I ſhall haue great ioy there, when he has borne away the widdow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why la, I thought where I ſhould find you preſently;
Vncle, a my troth, tis nothing ſo.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Whats nothing ſo ſir, is not he maried to the widdow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No by my troth is he not Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you haue the truth out, he is married to a whore ifaith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſhould laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vncle, let me periſh in your fauour if you find it not ſo and that tis I that haue married the honeſt woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha? Ide walke ten mile a foot to ſee that ifaith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And ſee'te you ſhall, or Ile nere ſee you agen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A Queane ifaith? ha, ha, ha.

div.stage: Enter Hoord taſting wine the Hoſt following in a Liuery cloake.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Pup, pup, pup, pup, I like not this wine, is there neuer a better Teirs in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Yes ſir, there are as good Teirs in the houſe, as any are in England.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Deſire your miſtris you knaue, to taſt e'm all ouer, ſhe • has better Skill.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Has ſhe ſo, the better for her▪ and the worſe for you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Arthur, is the cupbard of plate ſet out,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Al's inorder ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I am in loue with my Liueryes euery time I thinke on e'm, they make a gallant ſhow by my troth.—Neece.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: Do you call ſir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Prethee ſhow a litle diligence, and ouer-looke the knaues a litle, theile filtch and ſteale to day and ſend whole paſties home to their wiues, and thou bee'ſt a good Neece, do not ſee me purloynd.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: Feare it not ſir, I haue cauſe, tho the feaſt bee prepared for you, yet it ſerues fit for my wedding dinner too.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Maiſter Lamprey, and Maiſter Spichcocke two the moſt welcome gentlemen aliue, your fathers and mine were all free a • h Fiſhmongers.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: They were indeed ſir, you ſee bould gueſtes ſir, ſoone intreated

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And thats beſt ſir—how now ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Ther's a coach come to'th doore ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: My Ladie Foxeſtone a my life. Miſtris Iane Hoord, wife, maſſe tis her Ladyſhip indeed, Madame you are welcome to an vnfurniſht houſe, dearth of cheere, ſcarcſity of attendance.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You are pleaſd to make the worſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Is this your Bride.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Yes Maddam ſalute my Lady Foxtone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pleaſe you Madam a while to taſt the ayre in the garden?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Twill pleaſe vs well.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Who would not wed the moſt delitious life,
No Ioyes are like the comforts of a wife.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: So we bachilers thinke that are not troubled with them

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your worſhips brother with an other antient Gentleman, are newly allighted Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Maiſter Oneſiphorus Hoord, why now our company begins to come in: my deere and kind brother welcome ifaith.

sp.speaker: Ony:
sp.p: You ſee we are men at an hower brother.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I, Ile ſay that for you brother you keepe as good an hower to come to a feaſt, as any Gentleman in the Sheere▪ what ould Maiſter Limber and Maiſter Kicks, doe wee meete ifaith Iolly Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: We hope you lack gueſſe ſir?

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Oh welcome, welcome, wee lack ſtill ſuch gueſſe as your worſhips.

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Ah ſirrah brother, haue you catcht vp widdow Medler.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: From e'm all brother, and I may tell you, I had mighty enemies, thoſe that ſtuck ſore, old Lucre is a ſore foxe I can tell you brother.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Where is ſhe, ile go ſeeke her out, I long to haue a ſmack at her lips.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And moſt wiſhfully brother ſee where ſhe comes, giue her a ſmerck now we may heare it all the houſe ouer.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh heauen, I am betrayde, I know that face.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, why how now? are you both a ſhamde? come Gentlemen, weele looke another way—

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Nay Brother, harke you, come y'are diſpoſde to be merrie?

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Why do we meete elſe man?

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: That's another matter, I was nere ſo fread in my life but that you had beene in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How meane you brother?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: You ſayd ſhe was your wife?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Did I ſo? by my troth and ſo ſhe is.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: By your troth Brother?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What reaſon haue I to diſſemble with my friends, brother, if marriage can make her mine, ſhe is mine? why?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Troth I am not well of a ſuddaine? I muſt craue pardon brother, I came to ſee you, but I cannot ſtay dinner yfaith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I hope you will not ſerue mee ſo brother.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: By your leaue Maiſter Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What now? what now? pray Gentlemen, you were wont to ſhow your ſelues wiſemen.

sp.speaker: Lim,
sp.p: But you haue ſhowne your folly too much here.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Kix.
sp.l: Fie, fie, a man of your repute and name,
Youle feaſt your friends but cloye e'm firſt with ſhame.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: This growes too deepe pray let vs reach the ſence.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: In your old age doate on a Curtizan—

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Kixe.
sp.p: Marry a Srumpet?

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Ony:
sp.p: And Wit-goods queane:

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Oh, nor Lands, nor liuing?

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Liuing?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Speake?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alaſſe you know at firſt ſir,
I told you I had nothing:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Out, out, I am cheated, infinitely couzned.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay Maſter Hoord:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A dutch widdow, a dutch widdow, a dutch widdow:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why Nephew ſhall I trace thee ſtill a lier? wilt make mee mad is not yon thing the widdow.

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Why la, you are ſo hard a beleefe Vncle, by my troth ſhe's a whore.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: Then thou'rt a knaue:

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Negatur Argumentum Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Probo tibi, Nephew: Hee that knowes a woman to bee a queane muſt needes bee a knaue, thou ſayſt thou knowſt her to bee one, ergo if ſhee bee a queane thou'rt a knaue:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Negatur, ſequela maioris, Vncle, hee that knowes a woman to be a queane, muſt needes be a knaue, I deny that.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Lucre, and Wit-good, y'are both villaines, get you out of my houſe:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Why didſt not inuite me to thy wedding dinner?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And are not you and I ſworne perpetuall friends before wittneſſe ſir, and were both drunck vpon't.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Daintily abuſde y'aue put a Iunt vpon me:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A common ſtrumpet?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Nay now you wrong her ſir▪ if I were ſhee ide haue the lawe on you for that, I durſt depoſe for her, ſhee nere had common vſe, nor common thought.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Deſpiſe me, publiſh me I am your wife,
What ſhame can I haue now but youle haue part,
If in diſgrace you ſhare, I ſought not you:
You purſued me, nay forc'ſt me,
Had I friends would follow it,
Leſſe then your action has beene prou'd a rape.

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Brother?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Nor did I euer boaſt of lands vnto you,
Money or goods: I tooke a playner courſe:
And told you true ide nothing,
If error were committed twas by you.

thanke your owne folly, nor has my ſinne beene ſo odious but worſe has bin for giuen, nor am I ſo deformd but I may challing the vtmoſt power of any old mans loue, ſhee that taſts not ſin before, twenty to one but ſheele taſt it after: moſt of you ould men are content to mary yong Virgins and take that which followes, where marrying one of vs, you both ſaue a ſinner, and are quit from a cuckold for euer,
"And more in breife let this your beſt thoughts winne,
"She that knowes ſinne, knowes beſt how to hate ſinne.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Curſt be all Malice, blacke are the fruites of ſpite,
And poyſon firſt their owners: O my friends,
I muſt imbrace ſhame, to be rid of ſhame,
Conceald diſgrace preuents a publick name.
Ah Wit-good ah Theodorus,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alaſſe ſir, I was prick tin conſcience to ſee her well beſtowd▪ and where could I beſtowe her beter then vpon your pittifull worſhip: excepting but my ſelfe, I dare ſweare ſhees a Virgin, and now by marrying your Neece I haue baniſht my ſelfe for euer from her, ſhe's mine Aunt now by my faith, and theres no Medling with mine Aunt you know, a ſinne againſt my Nuncle.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Lo, Gentlemen, before you all.
In true reclaymed forme I fall,
Hence-forth for euer I defie,
The Glances of a ſinnefull eye,
Wauing of Fans, which ſome ſuppoſe,
Tricks of Fancy, Treading of Toes,
Wringing of Fingers, byting the Lip,
The wanton gate th' alluring Trip,
All ſecret friends and priuate meetings,
Cloſe borne letters, and Baudes greetings,
Fayning excuſe to weomens Labours,
When we are ſent for to'th next Neighbours,
Taking falſe Phiſicke, and nere ſtart,
To be let blood, tho ſigne be at heart,
Remouing chambers, ſhifting beds,
To welcome Frends in husbands ſteads,
Them to enioy, and you to marry,
They firſt ſerud, while you muſt tarry,
They to ſpend and you to gather,
They to get and you to father,
Theſe and thouſand thouſand more,
New reclaymed I now abhore.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A, heres a leſſon Rioter for you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe my follyes, Ile downe to
And Here for euer I diſclaime,
The cauſe of youths vndooing. Game:
Cheifly dice, thoſe true outlanders,
That ſhake out Beggars, Theeues and Panders,
Soule waſting Surfets, ſinfull Riotts,
Queanes Euills, Doctors diets.
Pothecaries Drugs, Surgeons Gliſters,
Stabbing of armes for a common Miſtris,
Riband fauours▪ Ribauld Speeches,
Deere perfumde Iacketts, pennyleſſe breeches,
Dutch Flapdragons, healths in Vrine,
Drabs that keepe a man to ſure in:
I do defie you all.
Lend me each honeſt hand, for here I riſe,
A reclaymde man loathing the generall vice.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.l: So, ſo, all friends, the wedding dinner cooles,
Who ſeeme moſt crafty proue oft times moſt fooles.
